E. Student Instructional Matters
Subject
1. Approval of English Learner Reclassification, Alternate Reclassification, and Master Plan
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No

RECOMMENDATION: Approve three documents related to the district's English Learner Master Plan which include updated criteria for Reclassification to include local assessments and Alternate Reclassification for Dually Identified English Learners. The documents are aligned to the state requirements and are in compliance with Federal Program Monitoring requirements.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: The documents were presented at the District English Learner Advisory Committee (DELAC) Executive Board on September 1, 2022; quorum was met. 

 

BACKGROUND:  Each district with 51 or more English Learners is required to develop a Master Plan that includes state policies and guidelines regarding implementation of English Learner educational programs and services.

 

[Originator/Contact: Marissa Allan, Instructional Support Officer, Office of Language Acquisition, Leadership and Learning, mallan@sandi.net, 619.725.7264]

F. Board Consent Agenda
Subject
3. Adoption of Resolution in the Matter of Recognizing October 10, 2022, as Indigenous Peoples Day
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No

RECOMMENDATION: Adopt resolution in the matter of recognizing October 10, 2022, as Indigenous Peoples Day in lieu of Columbus Day. The district encourages staff to utilize this day as an opportunity to teach the truth about US history and the impact that colonialism has had on Indigenous people. We commit to celebrate the thriving cultures and values of the Kumeyaay Nation, to reflect upon the ongoing struggles of the Indigenous people of this land, and to stand in solidarity with Indigenous peoples everywhere.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The San Diego Unified School District recognizes that the Indigenous peoples of the lands that would later become known as the Americas have occupied these lands since time immemorial. The district recognizes that the arrival of European explorers, colonists, and missionaries led to the genocide of Indigenous peoples of the land through slavery, violence, coercion, and disease. The district recognizes the fact that San Diego is built upon the unceded territory of the Kumeyaay Nation, without whom the building of the City would not have been possible. The district values the many contributions made to our community through Kumeyaay knowledge, labor, technology, science, philosophy, arts and the deep cultural contribution that has substantially shaped the charter of the City of San Diego. The district has a responsibility to oppose the systematic racism towards Indigenous people in the United States, which perpetuates high rates of poverty and income inequality, exacerbating disproportionate health, education, and social crises. The district must seek to combat prejudice and eliminate discrimination stemming from colonization and to promote awareness, understanding, and good relations among Indigenous peoples and all other segments of our district. The district promotes the closing of the equity gap for Indigenous peoples through policies and practices that reflect the experiences of Indigenous peoples, ensures greater access and opportunity, and honors our nation’s indigenous roots, history, and contributions. California State Assembly Bill 738, approved by the Governor on October 9, 2017, requires the state to develop a model curriculum that encourages school districts to offer a standards-based Native American studies curriculum. The San Diego Unified School District seeks to join the hundreds of other municipalities, school districts, and universities that recognize the second Monday of October as Indigenous Peoples’ Day to be observed as a day in solidarity with Indigenous peoples.

 

[Originator/Contact: Board Trustees, 619.725.5550, board@sandi.net]

File Attachments
Resolution Indigenous Peoples Day, 9-13-2022.pdf (113 KB)

Workflow

Workflow
Aug 29, 2022 1:22 PM :: Submitted by Melissa Hamilton. Routed to Marty Stultz for approval.
Sep 7, 2022 5:57 PM :: Final approval by Marty Stultz
F. Board Consent Agenda
Subject
4. Adoption of Resolution in the Matter of Recognizing September 15, 2022 through October 15, 2022, as National Hispanic Heritage Month
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No

RECOMMENDATION: Adopt resolution in the matter of recognizing September 15, 2022 through October 15, 2022, as National Hispanic Heritage Month and encourage teachers, other staff members, students, and the community to use this opportunity to honor the contributions of the Latinx population through student led activities and inclusive curriculum. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: During the Civil Rights Movement, the campaign to recognize the history, struggle, contributions, and achievements of Hispanic Americans gained traction. In 1968, California Congressman George E. Brown introduced House Joint Resolution 1299 to commemorate the contributions of Hispanic and Latinx Americans, authorizing President Lyndon B. Johnson to proclaim the week of September 15, 1968 as the first National Hispanic Heritage Week. In 1988, President Ronald Reagan declared September 15 through October 15 as National Hispanic Heritage Month. Hispanic Heritage Month begins on September 15th and ends on October 15th to coincide with the independence dates of five Latin American countries who declared their independence from Spain in 1821: Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, and Nicaragua. Hispanic Heritage week commemorates Chile’s independence from Spain on September 18, 1810. Hispanic Heritage week commemorates Mexico’s independence from Spain on September 16, 1821. Hispanic Heritage week commemorates Belize’s independence from Great Britain on September 21, 1981. Each year, Americans are encouraged to deepen their understanding of the Latinx community by celebrating the histories, cultures and contributions of Americans whose ancestors represent pre-Columbian civilizations included the Olmect, Maya, Zapotec, Teotihuacan, Mixtec, and Aztec, demonstrating kingdoms, empires, sophisticated cities, intellectual accomplishments and vibrant indigenous cultures developed in parts of Mexico, Central and South America, prior to Spanish conquest. The United States history includes indigenous cultures such as Latinx communities that express and demonstrate incredibly diverse cultures, represented by dialects, languages and richly historical cultures. Latinx and Hispanic people comprise 18.7 percent of the United States population, and 46.7 percent of the San Diego Unified student body. Latinx or Hispanic communities continue to contribute significantly to the political, economic, and social development of the nation. The San Diego Unified School District continues its commitment of eliminating barriers that prevent our Latinx students from receiving equitable access and its commitment to becoming an Anti-Bias Anti-Racist Restorative district that centers Ethnic Studies for all. The San Diego Unified School District recognizes the diversity reflected within the City of San Diego as well as its students and staff and respects the Latinx community’s contributions, culture, and heritage. The San Diego Unified School District recognizes the diversity represented within Latinx communities, such as Black and Indigenous Latinx populations, and commits to creating spaces where the identities of these students are represented and celebrated year-round. 

 

[Originator/Contact: Board Trustees, 619.725.5550, board@sandi.net]

File Attachments
Resolution Hispanic Heritage Month, 9-13-2022.pdf (116 KB)

Workflow

Workflow
Aug 29, 2022 1:25 PM :: Submitted by Melissa Hamilton. Routed to Marty Stultz for approval.
Sep 7, 2022 5:57 PM :: Final approval by Marty Stultz
F. Board Consent Agenda
Subject
5. Adoption of Resolution in the Matter of Recognizing September 2022, as National Suicide Prevention and Awareness Month
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No

RECOMMENDATION: Adopt resolution in the matter of recognizing September 2022, as National Suicide Prevention and Awareness Month and encourage educators, other staff members, students, and the community to use this opportunity to equip our youth with age-appropriate knowledge about mental health that is essential for suicide prevention as we actively seek to protect the wellbeing of students and save lives through suicide awareness education.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: September is National Suicide Prevention Awareness Month—a time to share resources and stories in an effort to shed light on this highly taboo and stigmatized topic of suicide. Suicide is the second leading cause of death for youth ages 10-14 and the third leading cause of death for youth ages 15-24, it is our district’s primary goal to protect the health and wellbeing of our students by emphasizing wellness, healthy lifestyles, suicide awareness and prevention strategies in all our schools. September is a month in which we continue our commitment to discussing the topic of suicide awareness and suicide prevention to assess the risk of, intervene in, and respond to suicide to save lives. Our schools during the month of September and ongoing will support suicide awareness to ensure students, friends and families have access to the resources they need to discuss suicide prevention. Suicide awareness and prevention efforts are to be implemented in our schools as we support suicide awareness among students and school communities, in order to understand suicide risk, contributing factors, and resources available to students and families in all schools. September is a month in which we collectively emphasize protective factors that decrease suicide risk factors in youth by: a) cultivating positive school climate and connections with students, their peers and school communities, b) providing students with opportunities to problem solve and build social and emotional competencies, and c) providing resources, mental health supports and interventions as needed.

 

[Originator/Contact: Board Trustees, 619.725.5550, board@sandi.net]

File Attachments
Resolution Suicide Prevention Month, 9-13-2022.pdf (110 KB)

Workflow

Workflow

Sep 7, 2022 5:57 PM :: Final approval by Marty Stultz
F. Board Consent Agenda
Subject
6. Adoption of Resolution in the Matter of Support for the Social Security Fairness Act (S. 1302/H.R. 82) and the Social Security 2100 Act (S. 3071/H.R. 5723) (Barrera/Bazzo)
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No

RECOMMENDATION: Adopt resolution in the matter of support for the Social Security Fairness Act (S. 1302/H.R. 82) and the Social Security 2100 Act (S. 3071/H.R. 5723).

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: San Diego, California and the nation have an urgent need to recruit talented new teachers into the profession. More than 2.5 million people dedicated to public service, including many educators, have their Social Security benefits reduced—or lose them entirely—due to unfair penalties. Unfair Social Security penalties paid by educators discourage people from joining the profession, especially those mid-career who stand to lose Social Security benefits they have already earned. The Windfall Elimination Provision (WEP) reduces the Social Security benefits of people who work in jobs covered by Social Security and jobs NOT covered by Social Security over the course of their careers—for example, educators compelled to take part-time or summer jobs to make ends meet. The Government Pension Offset (GPO) reduces the Social Security spousal or survivor benefits of people who get a government pension (federal, state or local) but did NOT pay Social Security taxes themselves. The GPO and WEP constitute an unfair tax on teacher retirement benefits. The Social Security Fairness Act (S. 1302/H.R. 82) and the Social Security 2100 Act (S. 3071/H.R.5723) will ensure public employees get the Social Security benefits they have earned by repealing both the GPO and the WEP. With a constantly increasing cost of living and no enhancements in 50 years, the Social Security 2100 Act would reaffirm the promise of retirement security and enhance benefits for the most vulnerable people in our communities. The Social Security Fairness Act has more than 260 co-sponsors in the House, enough to pass, and Social Security 2100 has about 200 co-sponsors in the House, short of the 218 needed if every member is present for the vote.

 

[Originator/Contact: Richard Barrera and Sabrina Bazzo, Board Trustees, 619.725.5550, board@sandi.net]

File Attachments
Resolution SSI Fairness Act, 9-13-2022.pdf (112 KB)

Workflow

Workflow
Aug 31, 2022 4:27 PM :: Submitted by Melissa Hamilton. Routed to Marty Stultz for approval.
Sep 7, 2022 5:58 PM :: Final approval by Marty Stultz
F. Board Consent Agenda
Subject
7. Adoption of Resolution in the Matter of Support for Climate Action (Barrera/Nepomuceno)
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No

RECOMMENDATION: Adopt resolution in the matter of support for Climate Action and encourage all professional educators to support student Global Climate Walkout events provided that educational outcomes are demonstrated (e.g., preparing an essay or video on the experience, documenting planning time). The San Diego Unified School District supports the free speech rights of every student, and will ensure students are able to help plan and participate in Global Climate Strike events in support of the Global Climate Strike on September 23, 2022.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change recently released their sixth and most dire assessment report yet, with UN Secretary-General António Guterres characterizing the report as “nothing less than a code red for humanity.” The World Meteorological Organization has recorded a fivefold increase in the number of weather, climate, and water-related disasters over the past 50 years, which will become even more frequent as a consequence of ongoing climate change. Record heat waves and fires continue to ravage California, with the American southwest in the most extreme drought in at least 1,200 years and a possible “mega storm” that could lead to flooding. Climate change is likely to increase the incidence of zoonotic disease, of which the consequences are clearly evident due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. COVID-19 has clearly demonstrated that disasters exacerbate existing social, economic, and racial inequalities. California leadership has recently introduced ambitious climate policy, including banning new gasoline-powered car sales by 2035, improving transit, and mandating 3,200-foot buffer zones between oil drilling sites and communities, but has failed to pass other emissions reductions targets. US leadership has made strides in recognizing the urgent need to combat the climate crisis by rejoining the Paris Agreement, setting ambitious emissions goals, and passing the Inflation Reduction Act, but has not yet passed all of the policies needed to achieve said emissions reductions. The San Diego Unified Board of Education has previously recognized the threat from global warming by calling on the California State Teachers’ Retirement System (STRS) and the California Public Employees’ Retirement System (PERS) to divest their investment portfolios of stocks in fossil fuel companies. The Board of Education has adopted Resolutions in Support of Community Choice Aggregation, PTA-Climate Change is a Children's Issue, and Supporting Climate Science Literacy. The San Diego Unified School District’s “Dream Big Solutions for a Sustainable Future” plan ensures district climate action and climate consciousness, and its Climate Action Plan commits to net-zero greenhouse gas energy emissions by 2035. San Diego Unified is taking steps towards meeting its goals by retrofitting schools with more efficient air conditioning and lighting systems; and more than 29,000 lighting fixtures have been converted to LED, offsetting 1,300 metric tons of CO2 gas emissions; and district solar energy systems will produce 38,250,000 kWhr/year of clean renewable energy by the end of 2022 that will offset 10,000 metric tons of CO2 emissions annually. San Diego Unified has funded the construction of hundreds of acres of parks and green spaces through the joint-use partnership with the City of San Diego; and reduced litter and plastic waste by nearly 4.7 million pieces through the replacement of utensil packets with individual forks, spoons, and napkins. Students from San Diego Unified have taken a leadership role in confronting global warming through participation in “Green Teams,” Eco Clubs, Environmental Justice Clubs, and other student groups. The “Love Food Not Waste” program has prevented 202,775 pounds of prepared food from ending up in landfills, provided 169,120 meals to the hungry, reduced food costs, and eliminated 110,107 pounds of CO2 gas emissions. The San Diego Unified School District has previously supported youth activists by adopting a resolution pressuring Governor Newsom to immediately phase out oil extraction. The San Diego Unified School District has supported prior student protests for the Global Climate Walkout in 2019 and 2021. There will be a Global Climate Strike and Walkout on September 23, 2022, led by youth climate leaders to demonstrate to world leaders at all levels of government that the people, especially the youth, are not satisfied with the insufficient response to climate change.

 

[Originator/Contact: Richard Barrera and Lea Nepomuceno, Board Trustees, 619.725.5550, board@sandi.net]

File Attachments
Resolution Climate Change, 9-13-2022.pdf (120 KB)

Sep 9, 2022 6:45 PM :: Final approval by Marty Stultz
G. Operational Matters Reserved for the Board
Subject
1. Approval of Revisions to Existing Administrative Board Policy (BP), Administrative Regulation (AR) and Exhibit (E)
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No

RECOMMENDATION: Approve revisions to existing Board Policy (BP), Administrative Regulation (AR) and Exhibit (E). Recommendation to approve is subject to any required negotiations pursuant to the Education Employment Relations Act (EERA). Redlined (edited) and clean versions of documents are attached for reference.

 

Board Policy (BP / Administrative Regulation (AR) / Exhibit (E) Title Description of Revision Reason
6158 Independent Study Revised to align with Assembly Bill 181. Changes in legislation regarding independent study. 

 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: The district does not believe that the recommendations contain substantive changes or have impacts associated with collective bargaining; however if any bargaining unit wishes to meet and clarify any recommended changes, they have been asked to contact the Labor Relations Department by September 23, 2022.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The proposed revisions include updates to Board Policies (BP), Administrative Regulations (AR) and Exhibits (E) to align with existing policy and reflect current district practice. 

 

In compliance with the Education Employment Relations Act (EERA), the Labor Relations Department has notified the applicable Bargaining Units of the proposed revisions to existing Administrative Regulations (AR) and Exhibits (E).

 

[Originator/Contact: Marty Stultz, Director, Board Services, 619.725.5550, mstultz@sand.net]

Last Name First Name Organization Industry Sector

BACKGROUND: The purpose of the Career Technical Education Advisory Committee (CTEAC) is to develop recommendations on the College, Career, and Technical Education program and to serve as liaison between the district and potential employers.

H. District Operations
Subject
1. Approval of Fiscal Year 2021-22 Unaudited Actuals Financial Report in Standardized Account Code Structure (SACS) Series Form (Education Code Section 42100)
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Budgeted
Yes

RECOMMENDATION: Approve the Fiscal Year 2021-22 Unaudited Actuals Financial Report in Standardized Account Code Structure (SACS) Series Form.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: The Fiscal Year 2021-22 Unaudited Actuals Financial Report shows a total General Fund ending balance of $216,223,396. Compared to the 2021-22 estimated ending fund balance of $195,942,147, this reflects an increase of $20,281,249. These balances are broken down below:

 

 

General Fund

2021/22 Unaudited Actual Ending Balance

2021/22 Estimated

Ending Fund Balance at Budget Adoption

Increase/ (Decrease)

 Unrestricted

 $       117,367,528

 $             106,615,761

 $     10,751,767

Restricted

 $         98,855,868

 $                89,326,386

 $       9,529,482

Total

 $       216,223,396

 $              195,942,147

 $     20,281,249

 

The estimated ending balance for 2021-22 that rolled into the beginning balance for the Adopted 2022-23 Total General Fund District Budget is $195,942,147. The 2022-23 adopted budget will be adjusted to reflect the increases in unrestricted and restricted general fund, as shown in the chart above, in the First Interim Report on December 2022.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: The Fiscal Year 2020-21 Unaudited Actuals Financial Report showed a total General Fund ending balance of $152,965,145. Compared to the 2020-21 estimated actuals ending balance at budget adoption of $116,532,261, this reflects an increase of $36,432,884.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND:  On May 20, 2003, the board approved the Single Budget Adoption Cycle for the district. The board adopted the 2021-22 budget on June 22, 2021. Under the Single Budget Adoption Cycle, California Education Code Section 42100 states that on or before September 15, the governing board of each school district shall approve, in the format prescribed by the Superintendent of Public Instruction, the Unaudited Actuals Financial Report of the district for the preceding fiscal year.

 

[Originator/Contact:  Zandy Macasinag, Director, Budget Development, Finance Division, 619.725.7597, amacasinag@sandi.net]

H. District Operations
Subject
2. Adoption of Resolution Authorizing The Issuance And Negotiated Sale Of Not To Exceed $100,000,000 Of Proposition S Bonds; Not To Exceed $150,000,000 Of Proposition Z Bonds And Not To Exceed $350,000,000 Of Measure YY Bonds Of San Diego Unified School District, Prescribing The Terms Of Sale Of Said Bonds, Authorizing The Preparation And Execution And Delivery Of One Or More Bond Purchase Contracts, Paying Agent Agreements, Fiscal Agent Agreements, Official Statements, Disclosure Dissemination Agent Agreements, And Investment Management Agreements For Said Bonds, And Authorizing The Execution Of Necessary Documents Relating To Said Bonds; Adoption of Resolution Authorizing And Directing The Issuance And Sale Of Not To Exceed $45,000,000 Of General Obligation Refunding Bonds And Not To Exceed $30,000,000 of Forward Delivery General Obligation Refunding Bonds Of San Diego Unified School District, Approving Forms Of And Authorizing Execution And Delivery Of A One or More Bond Purchase Contracts, Paying Agent Agreements, Escrow Agreements, Disclosure Dissemination Agent Agreements, Fiscal Agent Agreements, An Open Market Repurchase Agreement And Official Statements For Said Bonds, And Authorizing The Execution Of Necessary Documents Relating To Said Bonds; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action
Fiscal Impact
No
Budget Source
Not Applicable

RECOMMENDATION: 1. Adopt a resolution in the matter of authorizing the issuance and negotiated sale of not to exceed $100,000,000 of Proposition S bonds, not to exceed $150,000,000 of Proposition Z bonds and not to exceed $350,000,000 of Measure YY bonds of San Diego Unified School District, prescribing the terms of sale of said bonds, authorizing the preparation and execution and delivery of one or more bond purchase contracts, paying agent agreements, fiscal agent agreements, disclosure dissemination agent agreements, investment management agreements, and official statements for said bonds, and authorizing the execution of necessary documents relating to said bonds.

 

2. Adopt a resolution authorizing and directing the issuance and sale of not to exceed $45,000,000 of General Obligation Refunding bonds and not to exceed $30,000,000 of Forward Delivery General Obligation Refunding bonds of San Diego Unified School District, approving forms of and authorizing the preparation, execution, and delivery of one or more bond purchase contracts, paying agent agreements, escrow agreements, disclosure dissemination agent agreements, fiscal agent agreements, an open market repurchase agreement and official statements for said bonds, and authorizing the execution of necessary documents relating to said bonds.  

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: At an election held on November 4, 2008, the district sought authorization under Proposition S to issue general obligation bonds in an amount up to $2.1 billion. Proposition S was approved by more than 55 percent of district’s eligible voters voting on the proposition. Proceeds from the sale of the bonds are to be used by the district for the specific school facilities projects set forth in Proposition S.

 

At an election held on November 6, 2012, the district sought authorization under Proposition Z to issue general obligation bonds in an amount of up to $2.8 billion.  Proposition Z was approved by more than 55 percent of the district's eligible voters voting on the proposition. Proceeds from the sale of bonds are to be used by the district for the specific school facilities projects set forth in Proposition Z. 

 

At an election held November 6, 2018, the district sought authorization under Measure YY to issue general obligation bonds in an amount of up to $3.5 billion.  Measure YY was approved by more than 55 percent of the district's eligible voters voting on the proposition.  Proceeds from the sale of bonds are to be used by the district for the specific school facilities projects set forth in Measure YY.

 

The district has been issuing general obligation bonds on an ongoing and consistent basis under Proposition Z since the approval of Proposition Z in November 2012, and the approval. The district anticipates issuing refunding bonds to refinance formerly issued Proposition Z bonds at lower interest rates. The refunding bonds are expected to be issued in two series, one on a current delivery tax-exempt basis, and the other on a forward delivery tax-exempt basis.

 

As part of the current plan of finance for the Proposition S Bond Program the Proposition Z Bond Program and the Measure YY Bond Program, the district anticipates issuing one or more of the series of bonds under each authorization, as needed on an annual basis, until the full authorization has been issued.  The Bond issues will be structured so that tax rates necessary to pay debt service on the proposed bonds for each proposition or measure will not exceed $60.00 per $100,000 of assessed valuation, and otherwise in accordance with the respective Memoranda of Understanding with the County with respect to the Proposition MM bonds, Proposition S bonds and Measure YY bonds.  Good faith costs of issuance and repayment costs of the bonds have been presented to the board by its Municipal Advisor.

 

A Memorandum of Understanding between the district and County of San Diego, dated as of March 1, 2012, and revised by the district and the County with an effective date of June 1, 2019, was executed with respect to establishing an annual reserve for bonds issued under Proposition MM and Proposition S for the purpose of avoiding a fluctuating tax levy in accordance with Section 15250 of the Education Code. A Memorandum of Understanding between the district and County of San Diego, dated June 1, 2019, was executed with respect to establishing an annual reserve for bonds issued under Proposition Z for the purpose of avoiding a fluctuating tax levy in accordance with Section 15250 of the Education Code. A Memorandum of Understanding between the district and County of San Diego, dated June 1, 2019, was executed with respect to establishing an annual reserve for bonds issued under Measure YY for the purpose of avoiding a fluctuating tax levy in accordance with Section 15250 of the Education Code. Projected debt service schedules for the Bonds to be issued this year have been provided to assist the County in determining the tax levies and their uses for this fiscal year.

 

 

[Originator/Contact: Alicia Rolfe, Controller, Finance Division, 619-725-7672, arolfe@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
1. Approval of Field Trips; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)

RECOMMENDATION: Approve various elementary, middle, and secondary school field trips and related travel agency agreements and authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate these field trips.

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE:  Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Pursuant to Education Code Section 35330, the board approves educational field trips within the state and to other states, the District of Columbia, and foreign countries. The field trip requestor must follow district procurement guidelines as established by the Strategic Sourcing and Contracts Department. Requestors must communicate and submit all required intake forms, scopes of work, insurance documents, and other documents as needed to the Strategic Sourcing and Contracts Department 9 to 12 weeks prior to the field trip.

 

[Originator/Contact: Area Superintendents, 619.725.5550, board@sandi.net]

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $40,913.88 (This amount includes additional funds to cover unexpected expenses not captured by the venue Agreements until the final invoice is received by the school site.)

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On June 28, 2022, the board adopted a resolution delegating the authority to the Superintendent, the Chief Business Officer, the Chief Operations Officer, or the Director, Purchasing and Contracts to sign agreements on behalf of the Board of Education, for locations and venues for off-campus celebrations, and support services associated with these celebrations and special events. All of these Agreements for special events and support services are paid by the Associated Student Body (ASB) and booster funds. These Agreements are brought before the board for ratification and approval. This delegation of authority resolution helps expedite support to school ASB's in securing off-site venues and service vendors.

 

[Originator/Contact: Erin Richison, High Schools Area Superintendent, 619.725.5584, erichison@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
4. Approval of Agreement with University of San Diego to Provide Professional Development and Coaching to Curriculum Teachers at Creative Performing & Media Arts Middle School; BUDGETED: YES, MAGNET SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE PROGRAM FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$80,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Magnet Schools Assistance Program Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreement with University of San Diego to provide professional development and coaching to curriculum teachers at Creative Performing & Media Arts Middle School (PS22-1020-92). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is September 14, 2022 through March 31, 2026. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $80,000.00. Budget String: 0310-58220-22-5853-1000-1110-01000-0000. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The University of San Diego on behalf of its California Education Project will provide professional development and coaching to all curriculum teachers at Creative Performing & Media Arts Middle School to create teacher developed units.
 

This Agreement will support the development of professional learning and interdisciplinary, inquiry-driven instructional units in which students learn about the arts, with the arts, and through the arts based on state content standards. Teacher developed units will incorporate a variety of tools including: proficiency scales, standards-based rubrics, project-based learning, design thinking and inquiry-based instructional models.

 

[Originator/Contact: Mitzi Merino, Area 5 Superintendent, 619.725.7254, mmerino@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
5. Ratification of Agreement with Andrea L. Barraugh dba Math Transformations to Provide Math Professional Learning Content, Curriculum Planning Workshops, and Classroom Coaching for Logan Memorial Educational Campus; BUDGETED: YES, TITLE I BASIC PROGRAM FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$60,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Title I Basic Program Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with Andrea L. Barraugh dba Math Transformations to provide math professional learning content, curriculum planning, workshops, and classroom coaching for Logan Memorial Educational Campus (PS23-0280-77). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is June 8, 2022 through June 8, 2023.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total Not-to Exceed amount: $60,000.00. Budget String: 0358-30100-00-5100-1000-1110-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: Fiscal year 2021-22 total not-to-exceed amount: $24,900.00.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Math Transformations will provide tailored professional learning services to Logan Memorial Educational Campus math department teachers, to increase equitable experiences and improvements in math achievement for district students. Services include:

 

  • Tailored Grade Level Workshops
  • Unit Planning
  • Co-Teaching/Classroom Coaching
  • Vertical Collaboration Workshops
  • On-the-Spot Virtual Coaching/Support
  • Lesson Study

 

[Originator/Contact: Erin Richison, High Schools Area Superintendent, 619.725.5584, erichison@sandi.net]

Sep 6, 2022 11:53 PM :: Final approval by Drew Rowlands

Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$150,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Various Site Identified Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with Coast 2 Coast Coaching, Inc., to provide the district with sports activities with an emphasis on Social Emotional Learning (SV23-0183-92). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is August 1, 2022 through June 30, 2027. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $150,000.00. Budget String: Various Site Identified Funds. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of July 1, 2021 through June 30, 2022: $15,000.00. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

This districtwide Agreement is available to all school sites.

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
7. Ratification of Agreement with Girls, Inc., of San Diego County to Provide a Whole-Girl Health and Wellness Program to Help District Students to Overcome Gender, Economic and Social Barriers; BUDGETED: YES, VARIOUS SITE IDENTIFIED AND CSI FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$160,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Various Site Identified and CSI Funds

RECOMMENDATION:  Ratify Agreement with Girls, Inc. of San Diego County to provide a Whole-Girl Health and Wellness Program to help underserved district students to overcome gender, economic and social barriers on behalf of the Leadership and Learning Department (PS23-0113-25).  Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this service.  The term of this Agreement is July 1, 2022 through June 30, 2024. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $160,000.00; Various Site Identified and CSI Funds.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Girls, Inc. of San Diego County (GISD) will provide a holistic whole-girl health and wellness program.  This program inspires girls to be STRONG, SMART, and BOLD by assisting girls in San Diego to overcome gender, economic and social barriers with research-based programming.

 

The GISD program supports underserved girls throughout the county and helps overcome systemic inequity by motivating, deliberate, and interactive activities that develop and promote girls’ strengths.  This program guides girls to achieve their goals and aspirations despite their unique challenges.  This holistic, compensatory, and intentional approach exposure girls to a wide variety of relevant and field-tested curricula and experiences that confront the serious needs of girls while building the knowledge, skills, and attitudes to enable girls to be competent, confident individuals through adulthood. This program mentors relationships in a pro-girl environment that assists them in navigating gender, economic, and social barriers for girls ages 8 to 18.  This program also helps girls see college as attainable, resist peer pressure while learning essential life skills, and explore professional fields in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics) in which women are underrepresented.

 

 

[Originator/Contact:  Tavga Bustani, Chief, Leadership and Learning, 619.725.8115, tbustani@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
8. Ratification of Agreement with Marzano Resources, LLC, to Continue Providing Professional Development and Coaching to Participating Comprehensive Support Improvement Schools' Leadership on the High Reliability Schools Framework and Standards-Based Learning; BUDGETED: YES, COMPREHENSIVE SUPPORT IMPROVEMENT (CSI) FUNDS AND WILLIAM & FLORA HEWLETT FOUNDATION GRANT FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$332,475.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Comprehensive Support Improvement (CSI) Funds and William & Flora Hewlett Foundation Grant Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with Marzano Resources, LLC, to continue providing professional development and coaching to participating Comprehensive Support Improvement Schools' leadership on the High Reliability Schools framework and Standards-Based Learning (PS23-0240-92). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is August 21, 2022 through June 30, 2023. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $332,475.00. Budget Strings: 

5469-31820-23-5100-2140-0000-01000-0000 for $293,600.00 (CSI Funds)

5478-95469-00-5150-2140-0000-01000-0000 for $38,875.00 (William and Flora Hewlett Foundation Grant Funds)

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of July 1, 2021 through June 30, 2022: $284,650.00. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Marzano Resources, LLC, (Marzano) will continue providing participating CSI schools' leadership with professional development and coaching to support their improvement on the following California Dashboard indicators: chronic absenteeism, graduation rate, suspension rate, and academic achievement, through the implementation of Dr. Robert Marzano’s High-Reliability Schools (HRS) framework. The framework encourages educators to concentrate their efforts on five key areas of operation: 1. Safe, Supportive, and Collaborative Culture; 2. Effective Teaching in Every Classroom; 3. Guaranteed and Viable Curriculum; 4. Standards-Referenced Reporting; and 5. Competency-Based Education. The focus will be on the following:

 

1. Leading and sustaining a High-Reliability School.

2. Level 1 - Building a safe, supportive, and collaborative schoolwide culture.

3. Level 2 - 4 - Decreasing absenteeism by improving classroom instruction and the classroom environment. Increasing student learning in math and language arts by establishing a guaranteed and viable curriculum and an instructional model.

 

Marzano will also provide professional development focused on increasing academic achievement and providing a more equitable learning environment through the implementation of Standards-Based Learning practices to participating secondary schools’ leadership teams and school sites. Standards-Based Learning requires a dramatic shift in the existing curriculum, assessment, and reporting practices. 

 

[Originator/Contact: Tavga Bustani, Chief, Leadership and Learning, 619.262.2483, tbustani@sandi.net]

9. Approval of Agreement with Sean Tuohey dba Intellectual Athlete, LLC, to Provide Mind Body Professionals to Deliver the Play Built Resilience Curriculum to District Elementary and Middle School Sites; BUDGETED: YES, VARIOUS SITE IDENTIFIED FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$297,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Various Site Identified Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreement with Sean Tuohey dba Intellectual Athlete, LLC, to provide Mind Body Professionals to deliver the Play Built Resilience curriculum to district elementary and middle school sites (PS23-0323-92). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is September 13, 2022 through June 30, 2025. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $297,000.00. Budget String: Various Site Identified Funds. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Sean Tuohey dba Intellectual Athlete, LLC, will provide district elementary and middle school sites with Mind Body Professionals (IA Instructors) to deliver the Play Built Resilience curriculum, fusing sport, play and mindfulness.
 

Sean Tuohey dba Intellectual Athlete, LLC, will provide Mindfulness, Athletic Skill Development, Breathwork, Storytelling, and Team building instruction with the goal of teaching students how to self-regulate. The programs are for all students who are looking to improve their performance, manage their emotions, and acquire tools to overcome anxiety.

 

[Originator/Contact: Tavga Bustani, Chief, Leadership and Learning, 619.262.2483, tbustani@sandi.net]

Ratification of Agreement with The Regents of the University of California on Behalf of the University of California San Diego (UCSD) to Continue Providing UCSD Futures Coursework and Certificate Programs to Clairemont High School Students; BUDGETED: YES, K12 STRONG WORKFORCE CAREER DEVELOPMENT FUNDS

Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$60,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
K12 Strong Workforce Career Development Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratification of Agreement with The Regents of the University of California on Behalf of the University of California San Diego (UCSD) to continue providing UCSD Futures coursework and certificate programs to Clairemont High School students (PS23-0346-37). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is August 30, 2022 through June 30, 2023.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $60,000.00. Budget String: 5451-63884-00-5100-1000-3800-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The partnership with UCSD Extension to offer the Futures program courses empowers students to make informed decisions about college and career pathways. This program enables students to pursue their passions, explore new interests, and gain hands-on experiences before they enter the workforce or apply for college. Each program is designed specifically for students at Clairemont High School. The cutting-edge coursework is taught by leading industry experts in high-demand fields. Students have the opportunity to take three courses within each area, leading to a certificate. Certificate programs include Business Management, AutoCAD, and Programming and Architecture.

 

[Originator/Contact: Sarah Vielma, Director, College, Career, and Technical Education, Leadership and Learning, 858.503.1738, svielma@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
11. Ratification of Agreement with The Regents of the University of California on Behalf of the University of California San Diego (UCSD) to Provide College-Level Courses to District Students at Morse, La Jolla, and Point Loma High Schools; BUDGETED: YES, GENERAL FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$100,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
General Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratification of Agreement with The Regents of the University of California on behalf of the University of California San Diego (UCSD) to provide college-level courses to students at Morse, La Jolla, and Point Loma High Schools (PS23-0263-37). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of the Agreement is August 31, 2022 through June 30, 2023.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $100,000.00. Budget String: 5451-00007-00-5100-2150-3800-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The UCSD Extension college-level coursework program offers high-achieving students the opportunity to fulfill high school graduation requirements while gaining college preparation skills and lower-division transfer credits in science, technology, engineering, arts, and math disciplines. UCSD offers up to a total of ten courses to the participating sites. The courses are taught by UCSD Extension instructors. This program is grounded on the concept that academic rigor, combined with the opportunity to save time and money, is a powerful motivator for high school students to work hard in meeting the serious intellectual challenges of the future.

 

Participation in the program provides students with the opportunity to:

  • Increase the number of college credits they can earn while still in high school.
  • Make higher education more accessible, affordable, and attractive by bridging the divide between high school and college readiness.
  • Facilitate the transition of motivated high school students to higher education.
  • Create valuable opportunities to reach out to high school students and challenge students to utilize their high school careers in a fully productive manner.

 

For the 2022-23 year, student eligibility for the program includes meeting all course prerequisites, passing Integrated Math 3 or Intermediate Algebra, and completing the University of California 'a-g' course sequence.

 

[Originator/Contact: Sarah Vielma, Director, College, Career, and Technical Education, Leadership and Learning, 858.503.1738, svielma@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
12. Approval of First Amendment to Memorandum of Understanding between the San Diego Unified School District and the San Diego Community College District; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No
Budget Source
Not Applicable

RECOMMENDATION: Approve First Amendment to Memorandum of Understanding between the San Diego Unified School District and the San Diego Community College District (SV21-0276-92). The term of this agreement remains unchanged and is August 1, 2020 through August 1, 2025.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On July 28, 2020, the board approved a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with San Diego Community College District (SDCCD) to formalize the relationship between two institutions to collectively serve and benefit students in the San Diego community. The MOU serves as the Master Agreement for programs in which San Diego Unified School District high school students participate in classes on SDCCD campuses or virtually, and by which all individual educational partnerships are authorized.

 

This First Amendment adds the following to the MOU, and specifically to Article IX DATA SHARING/OWNERSHIP:

F. On an annual basis, the district will release to SDCCD, upon its request, student “directory information” as that term is defined in District Administrative Regulation 5125.1. To facilitate the release of such directory information, the district will include whatever information it deems necessary in its annual disclosures to parents pursuant to AR 5125.1. SDCCD agrees that it will not share any district student directory information with any third party, specifically including any charter school.

 

[Originator/Contact: Sarah Vielma, Director, College, Career, and Technical Education, Leadership and Learning, 858.503.1738, svielma@sandi.net]

Subject
13. Ratification of Agreement with America's Job Center of California, Partners, and the San Diego Workforce Partnership to Provide Inclusion in the Partner Programs List; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No
Budget Source
Not Applicable

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with America's Job Center of California (AJCC), Partners, and the San Diego Workforce Partnership (SDWP) to provide inclusion in the partner programs list (SV23-0348-77). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is July 1, 2022 through June 30, 2025.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act requires that a Memorandum of Understanding be developed and executed between the Local Workforce Development Board comprised of the AJCC, Partners, and SDWP. The district benefits by signing this Agreement as the Adult Education Programs will be included in the partner programs list. By inclusion in the partner program list, the AJCC Metro Center may refer prospective students to the district's Adult Education Programs. As a partner program, individuals between the ages of 18 and 19 will be referred to district Adult School for adult secondary education and adult basic skills services.


This Agreement is for outreach purposes only and at no cost to the district.

 

[Originator/Contact: Nicole DeWitt, Executive Director, Leadership and Learning, 619.725.8000, ndewitt@sandi.net]

Subject
14. Ratification of Agreement with National Conflict Resolution Center to Continue Providing Restorative Justice Practices Coordinators to District School Sites and Departments; BUDGETED: YES, TITLE II, PART A, SUPPORTING EFFECTIVE INSTRUCTION LOCAL GRANTS AND VARIOUS SITE FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$1,426,454.76
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Title II, Part A, Supporting Effective Instruction Local Grants and Various Site Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with National Conflict Resolution Center to continue providing restorative justice practices coordinators to district school sites and departments (PS23-0053-92). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement, with the delegation of authority to the Director, Purchasing and Contracts to exercise additional option terms provided for in the contract documents to extend the Agreement for up to two additional one-year terms, subject to the identification of budgeted funding sources. The initial term of this Agreement is July 1, 2022 through June 30, 2023.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $1,426,454.76. 

 

Total not-to-exceed amount for Year 1: $462,305.88; Budget String: 5393-40351-00-5100-2140-0000-01000-0000, $141,144.92 and Various Site Funds, $321,160.96.

 

Total not-to-exceed amount for option Year 2: $473,623.00; Budget String will be determined at a later date if the district decides to exercise this option to renew.

 

Total not-to-exceed amount for option Year 3: $490,525.88; Budget String will be determined at a later date if the district decides to exercise this option to renew.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of July 1, 2021 through June 30, 2022: $288,979.00. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: National Conflict Resolution Center will provide Restorative Justice Practices coordinators to district school sites and departments. Coordinators will provide professional development, coaching, capacity building, and reporting to students, families, school site staff, central office staff, and administrators.

 

These practices help students and staff embody the principles of safety, responsibility, respectfulness, appreciation of differences, create anti-bias and anti-racist learning environments, honesty, and lifelong learning.

 

[Originator/Contact: Nicole DeWitt, Executive Director, Leadership and Learning, 619.725.7772, ndewitt@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
15. Ratification of Agreement with Rady Children's Hospital-San Diego to Continue Providing Mental Health Services to District Students who Meet the Funding Eligibility Criteria Pursuant to the Federal and State Law; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No
Budget Source
Not Applicable

RECOMMENDATION:  Ratify Agreement with Rady Children's Hospital-San Diego to continue providing mental health services (at no cost to the district) to district students who meet the funding eligibility criteria pursuant to the federal and state law (PS22-0932-25).  Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this service.  The term of this Agreement is July 1, 2021 through June 30, 2024.  

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND:  Rady Children's Hospital-San Diego (Rady) is a non-profit agency that offers a full range of services for students' emotional well-being.  These services include treatment for outpatient psychiatry, inpatient eating disorders, child maltreatment, and behavioral health urgent care.

 

Rady has contracted with the County of San Diego to provide several behavioral health services throughout the city.

 

Rady will provide services to the district students and their families identified as traditionally underserved and unable to participate in community-based treatment services.

 

School-based mental health providers contracted by the County of San Diego, Behavioral Health Services (BHS), are known as SchooLink providers.  SchooLink is a partnership between the County of San Diego and local school districts to provide school behavioral health services.  This service is provided at no cost to the district.

 

[Originator/Contact:  Nicole DeWitt, Executive Director, Leadership and Learning, 619.725.5660,

ndewitt@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
16. Approval of Second Amendment to the Agreement to with the County of San Diego, Health and Human Services Agency to Continue Accepting Grant Funds for Physical Education Enhancement Programs at Various Elementary and Secondary Schools; BUDGETED: YES, REVENUE, COUNTY OF SAN DIEGO, HEALTH AND HUMAN RESOURCES GRANT FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$225,500.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Revenue: County of San Diego, Health and Human Resources Grant Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Second Amendment to the Agreement with the County of San Diego, Health and Human Services Agency to continue to accept grant funds for Physical Education Enhancement Programs at various elementary and secondary schools (SV20-0662-41). Authorize the execution of any documents to effectuate this revenue stream. The term of the Agreement extends the contract by one year for a new term of July 29, 2020 through September 30, 2023.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed revenue amount: $225,500.00 is added by this Second Amendment, for a new total not-to-exceed amount of $1,061,500.00. Revenue Budget String: 5457-91607-00-8699-0000-0000-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of July 1, 2020, through the present date the revenue not-to-exceed amount was $836,000.00.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On July 28, 2020, the board approved the original Revenue Agreement with the County to receive $600,000.00 for three years to enhance the physical education program in elementary and secondary schools across the district.

 

On July 27, 2021 the board approved the First Amendment to the Agreement to add $236,6000.00 for a not-to-exceed amount of $836,000.00.

 

This Second Amendment will add $225,500.00 in revenue for a new not-to-exceed total amount of $1,061,500.00 and extend the term by one year for a new term of July 29, 2020 through September 30, 2023. This will allow the district to continue to provide Physical Education Enhancement Programs at various elementary and secondary schools.

 

The County of San Diego, Health and Human Service Agency (HHSA), supports the Live Well San Diego vision of a region that is Building Better Health, Living Safely, and Thriving. Live Well San Diego, developed by the County of San Diego, is a comprehensive, innovative regional vision that combines the efforts of partners inside and outside the County government to help all residents be healthy, safe, and thriving. To the extent feasible, all HHSA partners and contractors are expected to advance this vision. Building Better Health focuses on improving the health of residents and supporting healthy choices. Living Safely seeks to ensure residents are protected from crime and abuse, neighborhoods are safe, and communities are resilient to disasters and emergencies. Thriving focuses on promoting a region in which residents can enjoy the highest quality of life.

 

[Originator/Contact: Nicole DeWitt, Executive Director, Leadership and Learning, 619.725.8000, ndewitt@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
17. Approval of Interdivisional Curriculum Committee (ICC) Recommendations
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No
Budget Source
Any costs associated with the proposed site adopted courses will be supported by the site

RECOMMENDATION:  Approve recommendations of the Interdivisional Curriculum Committee (ICC).  The course recommendations are detailed on the attached exhibit and consist of one Request to Pilot and 10 Uniform Course File changes.  

 

The ICC recommends:

 

Request to Pilot Course

 

  1. Pilot Musical Theatre Performance 1, 2 at Lincoln High School

 

Changes to the Uniform Course File

 

  1. Add English Language Arts SLIM (1691) to DePortola Middle School's Course Catalog
  2. Add Spanish Language Arts SLIM 6th (2369 ,2370) to DePortola Middle School's Course Catalog
  3. Add Social Studies 6th Spanish Cluster (6520D) to DePortola and Mann Middle Schools' Course Catalogs
  4. Add 7th Grade Integrated Science Spanish (6003D) to Taft Middle School's Course Catalog
  5. Add Spanish Language Arts SLIM 1-2 (2363,2364) to Mann Middle School's Course Catalog and Change Grade Level to 7-8 at Mann Middle School
  6. Change Arts Management 1,2 (8691,8692) to "g" (College-Preparatory Elective) Districtwide
  7. Change Biotechnology 3,4 (8730,8731) to "d" (Laboratory Science) Districtwide
  8. Change the grade levels of Theatre 5th–8th Intermediate (1458) 6-8 and change the course name to “Theatre 6th–8th Intermediate”
  9. Change the grade levels of Theatre 6th–8th Advanced (1459) to 7-8 and change the course name to “Theatre 7th–8th”  
  10. Add Clairemont High School to Sports Broadcasting 1,2 Honors (2607,2608) Pilot

 

ICC recommendations are based on the following criteria: (1) clear correlation to state academic standards; (2) an evaluation plan to judge the efficacy of the pilot course; (3) applicable fulfillment of University of California 'a-g' requirements; and (4) accordance with state education code provisions.

 

The ICC met via Zoom on August 25, 2022.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Any costs associated with the proposed site adopted courses will be supported by the site.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

                                                                                                

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE:  Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND:  The ICC is responsible for the assessment and recommendation of requests pertaining to the curriculum included in the district's Course of Study.  The ICC reviews and recommends new courses, deletion of courses, and changes to approved courses to the Board of Education. It ensures that all courses are rigorous and provide students with multiple pathways to graduation, college, and career. Revisions to the course of study are aligned with LCAP Goal 2.3.a.  The Committee is composed of the following members who are elected from among their peers, as stipulated by By-Laws that were adopted in September 2019:

 

  • 50 percent school site personnel, including two high school principals, two middle school principals, and one other administrator.

 

  • 50 percent central office personnel, including four program managers and one director.

 

[Original/Contact: Wendy Ranck-Buhr, Instructional Support Officer, Leadership and Learning, 619.725.7076, wranck-buhr@sandi.net]

File Attachments
9-13-22 ICC Recommendations.pdf (182 KB)

Subject
18. Approval of First Amendment to Agreement with Dr. Susan Yonezawa and Dr. Elizabeth Simon to Continue to Develop and Implement a New Computer Science Model for Grades 3-8; BUDGETED: YES, EDUCATION, INNOVATION AND (EIR) CODING OUR FUTURE GRANT FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$343,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Education, Innovation and Research (EIR) Coding our Future Grant Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve First Amendment to Agreement with Dr. Susan Yonezawa and Dr. Elizabeth Simon to continue to develop and implement a new computer science model for Grades 3-8 (PS21-0279-92). This First Amendment will increase the total not-to-exceed amount of the Agreement by $343,000.00 and will add two years to the original Agreement, revising the term to September 22, 2020 through September 21, 2024.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $343,000.00 for a new total not-to-exceed amount of $548,000.00.  Budget String: 5593-58275-00-1170-2140-3800-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of July 1, 2021 through June 30, 2022: $140,000.00.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On September 22, 2020, the board approved an Agreement with Dr. Susan Yonezawa and Dr. Elizabeth Simon to develop and implement a new computer science model for Grades 3-8, for a total not-to-exceed amount of $205,000.00, for the term from September 22, 2020 through September 21, 2022.

 

The district was awarded the U.S. Department of Education's Education, Innovation and Research Grant to accomplish the goals and objectives of the project, "Coding Our Future: Creating Equitable Computer Science Pathways in Urban Schools." The focus of the project is to develop and implement a new computer science model for Grades 3-8. The model will demonstrate how urban school districts can train teachers and empower students to learn computer science through in-depth teacher professional development and pathways of computer science courses. Dr. Susan Yonezawa and Dr. Elizabeth Simon will develop and implement an open-source Computer Science (CS) Educational Curriculum for the district. 

 

This First Amendment will allow Dr. Yonezawa and Dr. Simon to continue to develop and implement a new computer science model for Grades 3-8 by extending the original agreement for two additional years; thereby revising the original term to September 22, 2020 through September 21, 2024.

 

[Originator/Contact: Wendy Ranck-Buhr, Instructional Support Officer, Leadership and Learning, 619.725.5678, wranck-buhr@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
19. Approval of Agreement with the San Diego Police Foundation to Provide Internet Safety and Awareness Education for Children, Teens, Educators, Adults and Community Leaders; BUDGETED: YES, VARIOUS SCHOOL SITE IDENTIFIED FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$120,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Various School Site Identified Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreement with the San Diego Police Foundation to provide internet safety and awareness education for children, teens, educators, adults and community leaders (PS23-0130-18). The term of this Agreement is November 14, 2022 through November 12, 2027.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $120,000.00. Budget String: Various School Site Identified Funds.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The San Diego Police Foundation SafetyNet® program will provide internet safety and awareness education for children, teens, educators, adults and community leaders. Statistics reflect 34 percent of kids have been cyberbullied, one in five kids have been sexually solicited online, and 24 percent of teens have been involved in some type of sexting. Data shows 20 percent of high school students have met someone in person they first met on the internet, and identify thieves are targeting children at rates of up to 51 times higher than adults. Schools and parents are experiencing challenges in keeping up with the technology and tech savvy kids and may not have the knowledge or time to instruct them on the safe usage of technology.

 

The SafetyNet® program educates students with smart cyber choices. The program's primary goal is to educate students, parents/caregivers and educators about how to recognize and respond to potential online threats as well as how to manage their online presence. Topics include cyberbullying, predators, plagiarism, privacy, sexting, gaming, computer security, identity theft, and social networking.

 

[Originator/Contact: Wendy Ranck-Buhr, Instructional Support Officer, Leadership and Learning, 619.725.5678, wranck-buhr@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
20. Ratification of Agreement with Jewish Family Service of San Diego to Provide the “Breaking Down Barriers” Program to Approved School Sites; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No
Budget Source
Not Applicable

RECOMMENDATION:  Ratify Agreement with Jewish Family Service of San Diego to provide all approved schools with the “Breaking Down Barriers” Program on behalf of the Nursing and Wellness Department (PS23-0244-25).  Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this service.  The term of this agreement is July 13, 2022 through July 12, 2027.   

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Jewish Family Services of San Diego will provide the Breaking Down Barriers Program to district high school students at designated sites on behalf of the Nursing and Wellness Department.

 

Breaking Down Barriers is a mental health wellness prevention and early intervention program that supports underserved communities by providing outreach and educational services and a safe space to discuss any issues. 

 

The student population supported by this program includes: African American/Black; African/Refugee; Asian/Pacific Islander; Latinx/Latine; LGBTQIA+; Middle Eastern/Southwest Asian; North African; and Native American/Indigenous. The program will cover mental health stigma through these educational presentation events and provide the participants with helpful resources.

 

The district will secure all signed authorization forms from parents/guardians and submit them to the Jewish Family Services of San Diego staff. This service is provided at no cost to the district for the term of the agreement.

 

[Originator/Contact: Susan Barndollar, Executive Director, Nursing and Wellness, 619.725.5510, sbarndollar@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
22. Ratification of Agreement and Resolution with the California Department of Rehabilitation to Continue Providing Vocational Rehabilitation Services to Special-Needs Students Enrolled in the Transition Resources for Adult Community Education (TRACE) Program; BUDGETED: YES, REVENUE, DEPARTMENT OF REHABILITATION: TRANSITION PARTNERSHIP FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$775,760.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Revenue: Department of Rehabilitation: Transition Partnership Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement and Resolution with the California Department of Rehabilitation to continue providing vocational rehabilitation services to special-needs students enrolled in the Transition Resources for Adult Community Education (TRACE) program (PS23-0241-77; DOR 32065). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is July 1, 2022 through June 30, 2025.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed revenue amount: $2,378,010.00. Budget String: 0479-34100-00-XXXX-3110-5001-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of July 1, 2021 through June 30, 2022: $775,670.00.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The California Department of Rehabilitation (DOR) and the district are partnering to provide vocational rehabilitation services targeted at students ages 18 to 22 who have not received high school diplomas. Services include job placement assistance, recreation and leisure activities, life skills training, job coaching, job placement, mobility training, and referral to community agencies. Programs focus on personal growth, self-advocacy, and community access. The objective is for students to gain real work experiences in the areas of postsecondary education, vocational training, or adult education in order to achieve the ultimate goal of gainful employment in an integrated environment.

 

[Originator/Contact:  Sarah Ott, Executive Director, Special Education, 619.725.7650, sott@sandi.net]

PS23-0241-77_ORIGINAL_DOR_SIGNED BY LEGAL.pdf (4,812 KB)

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
23. Ratification of Agreement with Non-Public School (NPS) UHS of Doylestown, LLC, dba Foundations Behavioral Health to Provide Educational and Related Services to Identified Students With Disabilities; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No
Budget Source
Not Applicable

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with Nonpublic School (NPS) UHS of Doylestown, LLC, dba Foundations Behavioral Health, to provide educational and related services to students with identified special needs as mandated by state and federal law (PS22-1203-37). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is July 1, 2022 through June 30, 2023.

 

Additional NPS and NPA Agreements will be submitted for ratification at a later date.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: The fiscal impact for all 2022-23 NPS and NPA agreements was previously approved on June 28, 2022, at a not-to-exceed amount of $15,747,900.00. There is no additional fiscal impact as a result of this approval recommendation.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: The 2021-22 fiscal impact for all NPS and NPA agreements was $17,387,638.00.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On June 28, 2022, the board authorized payments to Nonpublic Schools (NPS) and Nonpublic Agencies (NPA) to continue providing special education and related services to students with exceptional needs as mandated by individual students' Individualized Education Programs (IEP) and by state and federal laws during the term of these Agreements.
 

The San Diego County Office of Education (SDCOE) collaborates with the SELPA directors from each of the County SELPAs to negotiate a template agreement to be used by each, which sets the terms, conditions, and rates for agreements with CDE-certified non-public schools and agencies.


When all negotiations are completed, this Master Contract, along with the approved rate sheets, is distributed to all school districts in San Diego County for the creation of individual agreements with identified CDE-approved NPS/NPA student services providers. Proposed NPS/NPA agreements are then submitted to the respective school boards for approval. In compliance with a provision in each Master Contract agreement which provides for payment at the currently approved rates to these providers until there is a ratification of a successor agreement. As individual Master Contracts are signed and returned to the district, they will be submitted for board approval.

 

[Originator/Contact: Sarah Ott, Executive Director, Special Education, 619.725.7650, sott@sandi.net]

Subject
24. Ratification of Agreement with Progressus Therapy, LLC, to Continue Providing Occupational Therapy (OT) Services to Students with Disabilities; BUDGETED: YES, SPECIAL EDUCATION OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$600,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Special Education Occupational Therapy Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with Progressus Therapy, LLC, to continue providing occupational therapy (OT) services to students with disabilities (PS23-0013-89). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is July 1, 2022 through June 30, 2023. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $600,000.00. Budget String: 5377-65000-00-5165-3140-5001-01000-0000. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of July 1, 2021 through June 30, 2022: $490,000.00.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The district does not have sufficient staff to provide related and specialized services to district students with identified or suspected disabilities as specified in their Individual Education Programs (IEP) and as mandated under state and federal special education laws. The district established a pool of qualified providers to meet the needs of these students.

 

California Government Code 53060 grants the district authority to contract with and employ persons for the furnishing to the district of special services if such persons are specially trained, experienced, and competent to perform the special services required.

 

[Originator/Contact: Sarah Ott, Executive Director, Special Education, 619.725.7650, sott@sandi.net]
