Subject
25. Ratification of Agreement with Progressus Therapy, LLC, to Continue Providing Physical Therapy (PT) Services to Students with Disabilities; BUDGETED: YES, SPECIAL EDUCATION PHYSICAL THERAPY
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$250,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Special Education Physical Therapy Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with Progressus Therapy, LLC, to continue providing physical therapy (PT) services to students with disabilities (PS23-0021-89). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement.  The term of this Agreement is July 1, 2022 through June 30, 2023.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $250,000.00. Budget String: 5377-65000-00-5161-3140-5001-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of July 1, 2021 through June 30, 2022: $280,000.00. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: This Agreement with Progressus Therapy, LLC, will allow the district to continue providing physical therapy services to students with disabilities.

 

The district has established a pool of qualified providers to meet the needs of the students, as it does not have sufficient staff to provide the related and specialized services to its students identified or suspected disabilities as specified in the IEPs.

 

California Government Code 53060 grants the district the authority to contract with and employ persons to furnish special services if such persons are specially trained, experienced, and competent to perform the special services required.

 

[Originator/Contact: Sarah Ott, Executive Director, Special Education, 619.725.7650, sott@sandi.net]

Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$380,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Special Education Vision Therapy Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with Total Vision PC to continue providing vision assessment and vision therapy services to students with special needs (PS23-0016-89).  Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement.  The term of the Agreement is July 1, 2022 through June 30, 2023.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $380,000.00. Budget String: 5377-65000-00-5162-3140-5001-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of July 1, 2017 through June 30, 2022: $1,633,630.00.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: This Agreement will continue providing vision assessment and/or vision therapy services to special needs students with identified or suspected needs as mandated in each student's Individual Education Plan (IEP) and in compliance with state and federal special education laws.

 

California Government Code section 53060 allows a school district to contact with and employ any persons for the furnishing of special services if such persons are specially trained, experienced and competent to perform the special services required.

 

[Originator/Contact: Sarah Ott, Executive Director, Special Education, 619.725.7650, sott@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
27. Ratifications of Agreements with Multiple Providers to Continue Providing American Sign Language Interpreting and/or Transcribing Services to Deaf or Hard of Hearing or Deaf/Blind Students, Staff, and Community Members for All Events/Activities Including Sporting Events Occurring within the District and/or Specified in the Individualized Education Plan (IEP) and Mandated Under State and Federal Laws and Regulations; BUDGETED: YES, SPECIAL EDUCATION NON-PERSONNEL FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$235,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Special Education Non-Personnel Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreements with multiple providers to continue providing American Sign Language interpreting and/or transcribing services to deaf or hard of hearing or deaf/blind students, staff, and community members for all events/activities including sporting events occurring within the district and/or specified in the Individualized Education Plan (IEP) and mandated under state and federal laws and regulations (PS23-0312-37 and PS23-0313-37). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate these Agreements. The term of these Agreements is July 1, 2022 through June 30, 2027. The providers are
Deaf Community Services of San Diego, Inc. (PS23-0312-37) and Global Captioning Solutions, Inc., dba eCaptions (PS23-0313-37).

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $235,000.00; Deaf Community Services of San Diego, Inc. $85,000.00; Global Captioning Solutions, Inc., dba eCaptions $150,000.00; Budget String: 5388-65000-00-5163-1130-5750-01000-4371.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: These Agreements will provide the district with multiple vendors that will provide both in-person and online CART or Transcription Services and/or interpretation services to Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing students, staff, and community members, as applicable, for all events/activities occurring within the realm of the district and/or specified in the Individualized Education Plan (IEP) and mandated under state and federal laws and regulations.

 

The district does not have sufficient staff to provide American Sign Language (ASL) Interpreting and/or transcribing services to district students, staff, and community members, as applicable, for all events/activities occurring on district property and/or specified in district students' Individualized Education Plans (IEP) and mandated under state and federal laws. The district is required to contract with outside agencies to provide ASL, transcription, or CART (computer-aided, real-time) services due to district employees taking leave and for situations where existing staff are unavailable. The district also does not currently have a substitute pool for the positions of Educational Transcribers. These Agreements will provide interpreters and/or transcribers when district staff is insufficient and/or unavailable.

 

California Government Code 53060 grants the district the authority to contract with and employ persons for the furnishing to the district of special services if such persons are specially trained, experienced, and competent to perform the special services required.

 

[Originator/Contact: Sarah Ott, Executive Director, Special Education, 619.725.7650, sott@sandi.net]

Subject
28. Ratification of Agreement with the Regents of the University of California to Continue Providing Induction Programming for Eligible District Teachers; BUDGETED: YES, TITLE II, PART A, SUPPORTING EFFECTIVE INSTRUCTION LOCAL GRANT FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$5,200,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Title II, Part A, Supporting Effective Instruction Local Grant Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with the Regents of the University of California to continue providing induction programming for eligible district teachers (PS23-0189-92). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is August 1, 2022 through July 31, 2027.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $5,200,000.00. Budget String: 5469-40351-00-5100-2140-0000-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of July 1, 2021 through June 30, 2022: $520,000.00.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The Regents of the University of California on behalf of the University of California, San Diego will provide induction programming to district teachers with preliminary credentials. This Agreement will provide a California Commission on Teacher Credentialing approved program that meets the requirements for teachers to receive a professional Clear Credential. It is a two-year process within the accredited program with an Early Completion Option for qualified candidates to complete requirements in one year. 

 

[Originator/Contact: Heather Harris, Program Manager, Teacher Preparation and Support, Leadership and Learning, 858.937.2700, hharris@sandi.net]

Subject
29. Ratification of Agreement with Regents of the University of California on behalf of the University of California, San Diego to Continue Providing Student Teacher Placements in District Schools; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No
Budget Source
Not Applicable

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with Regents of the University of California on behalf of the University of California, San Diego to continue providing student teacher placements in district schools (PS22-0961-92). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is July 1, 2022 through June 30, 2027.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: This Agreement authorizes the University of California, San Diego, as an accredited teacher training institution, to provide supervised teaching experiences in selected district schools to university students attempting to secure a California Preliminary Teaching Credential. There is no cost to the district, as the university provides stipends to district teachers for serving as supervising teachers.

 

Both the district and the University of California, San Diego benefit from this partnership that provides educational fieldwork experiences and learning opportunities to student teachers.

 

[Originator/Contact: Heather Harris, Program Manager, Teacher Preparation and Support, Leadership and Learning, 858.937.2700, hharris@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
32. Ratification of Certificated and Classified Personnel Actions and Ratification of Discipline Settlement Agreements; BUDGETED: YES, VARIOUS FUNDS
Meeting

Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact

Dollar Amount
$47,080.82
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Various Funds

RECOMMENDATIONS: Ratify certificated and classified personnel actions and discipline settlement agreements.  

 

  1. Ratification of certificated and classified personnel actions processed by the Human Resources Services Division from July 8, 2022, through August 26, 2022, including: hires, re-hires, promotions, transfers, terminations, pay rate changes and assignment changes; and
  2. Ratification of discipline settlement agreements with certificated and classified district employees from May 6, 2022, through September 13, 2022. These disciplinary actions affect a total of 7 employees: 4 resignations and 3 suspensions. Disciplinary actions by bargaining unit are as follows:

Subject
33. Approval of Revisions to District Conflict of Interest Code, Designated Positions; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No

RECOMMENDATION: Approve revisions to Appendix 1, and authorize the revised Appendix 1 to be sent to the San Diego County Board of Supervisors for further review and consideration.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Under California Government Code section 87300 and following, local governmental agencies such as cities, counties and school districts, are required to adopt and periodically update a Conflict of Interest Code which requires disclosure of certain financial interests on Fair Political Practices Commission Form 700, Statement of Economic Interests.

 

The Board of Supervisors for each county serves as the code-reviewing body, and works with local agencies to ensure that the agency's Conflict of Interest Code (reflected in Administrative Regulation 3700), the list of Designated Positions (Appendix 1) and the Categories of Reportable Economic Interests (Appendix 2) are reviewed and updated as necessary biennially during even-numbered years.

 

Since the last revision of Appendix 1 two years ago, a number of position changes have been made by the district.  Attached are both a clean, proposed Appendix 1 and a red-line version of Appendix 1 which shows positions to be added to the list of required filers as underlined, and designated positions to be deleted as lined out.

 

[Originator/Contact: Andra M. Greene, General Counsel, 619-725-5630, amgreene@sandi.net

File Attachments
Designated Positions - redline for 2022 - final.pdf (143 KB)
Designated Positions - clean for 2022 - final.pdf (141 KB)

Aug 29, 2022 7:23 PM :: Final approval by Andra M Greene

Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$6,680.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Finance Division Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with School Services of California, Inc., to continue providing fiscal and state-mandated cost information services to the district (PS23-0326-18). The term of this Agreement is September 1, 2022, through August 31, 2023. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $6,680.00. Budget String: 5241-00005-00-5853-7200-0000-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of September 1, 2021, through August 31, 2022: $6,680.00.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: This agreement continues to provide the district with information related to school finance, legislation, school budgeting, general fiscal issues, and the state-mandated program cost claims process. It also provides the district, on an as-required basis, with technical assistance on budgeting, comparative reports on district revenues, expenses, and certificated non-management salaries and benefits.

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
42. Approval of Resolution to Establish Estimated 2022-23 Appropriations Limit and the Actual 2021-22 Appropriations Limit; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No
Budget Source
Not Applicable

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Resolution to establish the estimated 2022-23 appropriations limit at $986,788,016.35 and the actual 2021-22 appropriations limit at $893,829,117.73 in accordance with Article XIII-B of the California Constitution.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND:  The district's 2022-23 final budget is in conformance, pursuant to Article XIII-B and related legislation. On November 6, 1979, Article XIII-B of the California Constitution was adopted establishing appropriations limits for state and local governments. California Government Code sections 7900 et seq. require the governing body of each local jurisdiction to establish its appropriations limit each fiscal year.

 

[Originator/Contact: Zandy Macasinag, Director, Budget Development, Finance Division, 619.725.7597, amacasinag@sandi.net]

43. Acceptance and Approval of Disclosure of District Investments and Cash on Hand for Quarter Ending June 30, 2022; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No
Budget Source
Not Applicable

RECOMMENDATION: Accept and approve the report on the district’s investments and performance, along with the district’s cash on hand for the quarter ending June 30, 2022.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total district investments of $2,483,658,111.20 include cash on hand of $1,769,290,653.39. In addition to this amount, $711,143,608.42 is invested in the San Diego County Investment Pool. The balance of the funds $3,223,849.39 are held at various institutions under management of contracted parties. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Prior to the suspension of the investment reporting mandate, the law required that the district’s cash and investments be reported to the board on a quarterly basis. As a matter of practice, the district continues to report to the board all monies held in the San Diego County Treasury Investment Pool and all Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) insured accounts in banks and credit unions.

 

[Originator/Contact: Alicia Rolfe, Controller, Finance Division, 619.725.7171, arolfe@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
44. Approval or Ratification of Private School Agreements for Services Provided at Various Private School Sites; BUDGETED: YES, VARIOUS SITE IDENTIFIED FUNDS

Various Site Identified Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve or ratify Private School Agreements for services provided at various private school sites. The terms of these Agreements are listed below:

 

 

School/Site

Agreement Number

Contractor Name

Agreement Term

Not-to-Exceed Amount & Budget String

Statement of Service

 

 

Open to All Eligible Non-Profit and Non-Public Private Schools

 

 

 

 

 

SV23-0092-37

Play It Safe Defense, Inc.

September 14, 2022 to September 14, 2027

$56,250.00

 

Budget String: various-41272-22-5801-1000-1110-01000-0000

 

Title IV, Part A

Independent Contractor will provide eligible students attending eligible Non-profit or Nonpublic Private Schools participating

in the Title I, Part A program managed by the district, with grade level appropriate assemblies on topics related to Bully

Prevention and Stranger Awareness and Safety.

 

Soille San Diego Hebrew Day School

3630 Afton Rd, San Diego, CA 92123

 

 

SV23-0118-37

Grace C.L. Fantaroni

August 15, 2022 to June 3, 2023

$9,000.00

 

Budget String: 0769-40353-22-5801-2140-0000-01000-0000 and 0769-40353-23-5801-2140-0000-01000-0000

 

Title II, Part A

Independent Contractor will provide training and consultation to non-certificated teachers and staff.

 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount of each agreement is listed in the table above. Budget Strings are listed above.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Under ESEA as amended by ESSA Section 8501 (a)(4), districts receiving federal funds under Title IV-A, Supporting Student Enrichment, must provide equitable services to eligible nonprofit private school children, their teachers, and other educational personnel serving those children. Services and other benefits to private schools’ students must be secular, neutral, and non-ideological, must be provided in a timely manner, and must be equitable in comparison to service and other benefits for public school children, teachers, and other educational personnel. Districts receiving ESSER or GEER funds must, for any activities supported by ESSER or GEER funds, also provide equitable services to private schools in the same manner as provided under the ESEA as amended by ESSA. 

 

Originator/Contact: Mary Johnson, Program Manager, Private School Services, Finance Division, 619.725.5611, mjohnson8@sandi.net]

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $49,153.96. Budget String: Various Identified Funds.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: These transactions are submitted to the board for review pursuant to Education Code sections 17604 and 17605 and under its delegation of authority to the district Strategic Sourcing and Contracts Officer for the benefit of the Private Schools Department. This board agenda item allows for efficiency in the administration of a large urban school district, California Education Code section 17605 specifically allows a school district to delegate limited purchasing power, i.e., for purchases no greater than $99,100.00, adjusted annually in accordance with the Public Contract code bid threshold.

 

[Originator/Contact: Mary Johnson, Program Manager, Private School Services, Finance Division, 619.725.5611, mjohnson8@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
46. Approval of Agreement with George Couros to Provide a One-Day Professional Development Presentation to the Catholic Diocese of San Diego for Participating Catholic School Staff Attendees; BUDGETED: YES, TITLE II, PART A FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$9,500.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Title II, Part A Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreement with George Couros to provide a one-day Professional Development Presentation to the Catholic Diocese of San Diego for participating catholic school staff attendees (PS23-0205-37). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is October 1, 2022 through October 30, 2022.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $9,500.00. Budget String: 0947-40353-23-5801-2140-0000-01000-0000

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The presentation will build on the concepts presented in the book, "Innovate Inside the Box," by Katie Novak and George Couros. The keynote will focus on how teachers and administrators can ensure that limitations do not impede authentic learning. George Couros will discuss how to create purposeful learning opportunities for all students by combining the power of the Innovator's Mindset and UDL. UDL is an educational framework based on decades of neuroscience research and is endorsed by the Every Student Succeeds Act (ESSA). This framework is being adopted by teachers, schools, and districts around the globe and is considered best practice for teaching ALL students in an inclusive learning environment. UDL empowers both teachers and students by putting students in charge of their own learning.

 

Participants in the breakout session will use UDL to proactively design learning experiences that foster voice and choice while addressing barriers that impede learning. They will also work to create learner-driven, evidence-informed learning experiences that provide all students with options and choices to maximize success.

 

[Originator/Contact: Mary Johnson, Program Manager, Private School Services, Finance Division, 619.725.5611, mjohnson8@sandi.net]

File Attachments
PS23-0205-37_ORIGINAL_George Couros_signed by legal 8.23.22.pdf (1,732 KB)

Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact

Dollar Amount
$33,700.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Title II, Part A Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratification of Agreement with Solution Tree, Inc., to provide professional development services for the Diocese of San Diego nonprofit private schools located within the boundaries of the district (PS23-0117-37). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is July 27, 2022 through September 30, 2023.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $33,700.00. Budget Strings: 0947-40353-22-5801-2140-0000-01000-0000 and 0947-40353-23-5801-2140-0000-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Solution Tree, Inc., will provide professional development sessions focused on Professional Learning Communities at Work (PLC at Work). There will be two PLC at Work associates providing training sessions. Karen Power will present three onsite PLC at Work sessions and Sarah Schuhl will present two onsite PLC at Work sessions for Diocese teachers. The PLC at Work associate will work with the Diocese administrator to customize these sessions based on the participant's current PLC at Work reality. The sessions will focus on deepening participants' understanding of the PLC at Work processes and addressing critical next steps to further their PLC at Work implementation. 

 

[Originator/Contact: Mary Johnson, Program Manager, Private School Services, Finance Division, 619.725.5611, mjohnson8@sandi.net

48. Ratification of Agreement with Blocksi, Inc., to Provide a Software Management Tool to Allow Data Sharing of User Information; BUDGETED: YES, INTEGRATED TECHNOLOGY SUPPORT SERVICES DEPARTMENT FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$118,800.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Integrated Technology Support Services Department Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with Blocksi, Inc., to provide a software management tool to allow data sharing of user information (SW22-1196-18). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The initial term of this Agreement is May 23, 2022 through July 31, 2023, with the delegation of authority to the Strategic Sourcing and Contracts Director to exercise additional two one-year options to renew, subject to the identification of a budgeted funding source.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount for initial term: $39,600.00. Budget String: 5538-00005-00-5841-7700-0000-01000-0000.

Total not-to-exceed for renewal option year 1: $39,600.00. Budget String will be determined at a later date if option is exercised.

Total not-to-exceed for renewal option year 2: $39,600.00. Budget String will be determined at a later date if option is exercised.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: This is a data sharing agreement between Blocksi, Inc., and the district to pilot Blocksi, the classroom management tool provided by Blocksi, Inc., that empowers teachers by giving them a simple and efficient management tool that provide real time monitoring and intervention on the student Chromebooks within their classrooms. It allows the teacher, at a glance, through the Blocksi dashboard the ability to monitor student activity during class. It promotes safe and appropriate internet usage and provides teachers with assistance with keeping students on task. This classroom management product was piloted from May 23, 2022 through July 31, 2022 by iHigh teachers and home hospital teachers the last few weeks of school and then by any teachers that wished to pilot during the summer. From August 1, 2022 through July 31, 2023 paid subscription services will be available for Blocksi's classroom management tool for 22,000 students.

[Originator/Contact: Toren Allen, Executive Director, Integrated Technology Division, 619.260.5438, tallen@sandi.net]

49. Ratification of Agreement with Broadway Typewriter Company, Inc., DBA Arey Jones Educational Solutions to Provide Apple Device Integration Services; BUDGETED: YES, VARIOUS SITE IDENTIFIED FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$750,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Various Site Identified Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with Broadway Typewriter Company, Inc., dba Arey Jones Educational Solutions to provide Apple device integration services (PS23-0265-18). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is July 1, 2022 through June 30, 2027.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $750,000.00. Budget String: Various site identified funds.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: When Apple computers and tablets are purchased by schools and departments, integration services are required to ensure the devices are consistently configured to be compatible with the district's computing infrastructure and in a secure manner. These services also provide the application of a laser etching thief deterrent to the device, asset tagging and data reporting, and onsite delivery/setup. Historically, the district has procured these services directly from Apple who sub-contracted with a service provider. By contracting directly with a service provider, the district will realize a cost savings and have greater flexibility to obtain the desired services.

 

[Originator/Contact: Toren Allen, Executive Director, Integrated Technology Division, 619.260.5438, tallen@sandi.net]

Subject
50. Ratification of Agreement with CDW Government, LLC, to Provide Multi-Factor Authentication Software as a Service for District Staff; BUDGETED: YES, INTEGRATED TECHNOLOGY SUPPORT SERVICES DEPARTMENT FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$583,415.50
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Integrated Technology Support Services Department Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratification of Agreement with CDW Government, LLC, to provide Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) software as a service for district staff (SW23-0069-18). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The initial term of this Agreement is July 1, 2022 through June 30, 2025, with the delegation of authority to the Strategic Sourcing and Contracts Director to exercise additional two one-year options to renew, subject to the identification of a budgeted funding source.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount for the initial term: $339,815.50. Budget Strings: 5538-00006-00-5841-7700-0000-01000-0000 and 5538-00005-00-4301-7700-0000-01000-0000.

Total not-to-exceed for renewal option year 1: $118,800.00. Budget String will be determined at a later date if option is exercised.

Total not-to-exceed for renewal option year 2: $124,800.00. Budget String will be determined at a later date if option is exercised.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: As part of the district's cyber-security roadmap, the Integrated Technology Division has deployed Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for staff to access certain district computing services. MFA software provides an additional layer of security to a district user account by requiring an extra verification step in addition to a password, before granting access to a computer system(s). Login credentials are more valuable than ever and are increasingly easy to compromise. Over 90 percent of breaches today involve compromised usernames and passwords. The district began utilizing DUO MFA in 2019 to protect the highest privileged user accounts, and now will expand service to all district accounts.

 

[Originator/Contact: Toren Allen, Executive Director, Integrated Technology Division, 619.260.5438, tallen@sandi.net]

53. Approval of Agreement with CVR Computer Supplies, Inc., to Provide OEM LaserJet Toner and Printer Ink; BUDGETED: YES; VARIOUS SITE IDENTIFIED FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$913,500.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Various Site Identified Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreement with CVR Computer Supplies, Inc., (GD22-0693-41) to provide OEM LaserJet toner and printer ink. Authorize the execution of all necessary documents to effectuate the Agreement. The term of this Agreement is September 13, 2022, through July 25, 2025. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $913,500.00. Budget String: Various Site Identified Funds. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Public Contract Code Section 20111 allows a school district to let contract for goods or services exceeding $99,100.00.

 

On April 14, 2022, the district issued a three-year term bid (GD22-0693-41), via PlanetBids, for OEM LaseJet Toner and Printer Ink.

 

Item 1 - HP 58A Black Original LaserJet Toner Cartridge

Item 2 - HP 212A Black Original LaserJet Toner Cartridge

Item 3 - HP 212A Cyan Original LaserJet Toner Cartridge

Item 4 - HP 212A Yellow Original LaserJet Toner Cartridge

Item 5 - HP 212A Magenta Original LaserJet Toner Cartridge

Item 6 - HP 147A Black Original LaserJet Toner Cartridge

Item 7 - HP 655A Black Original LaserJet Toner Cartridge

Item 8 - HP 655A Cyan Original LaserJet Toner Cartridge

Item 9 - HP 655A Yellow Original LaserJet Toner Cartridge

Item 10 - HP 655A Magenta Original LaserJet Toner Cartridge

 

Award of the Agreement shall be based on the lowest total lot (section), line item, or total bid; whichever results in the lower overall cost for the district. Recommendation for award will go to the apparent responsive and responsible bidder(s) with the lowest total lot/bid amount and the highest discount of manufacturer’s list price.

 

On May 31, 2022 at 1:00 p.m., the public bid opening was conducted via PlanetBids. The district received the following six bids (in alphabetical order):

 

1. CVR Computer Supplies, Inc.

2. Meredith Digital, Inc.

3. Office Depot 

4. Rasix Computer Center, Inc.

5. Staples 

6. The Tree House, Inc.

 

The Tree House, Inc. was found to have a non-responsive bid.

 

Therefore, it is in the best interest of the district to award Bid No. GD22-0693-41 as follows:

 

 

Items(s) Awarded

Contract #

Vendor

Amount

1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9, and 10

GD22-0693-41

CVR Computer Supplies INC.

$913,500.00

 

 

[Originator/Contact: Tyler Rudolph, Director, Integrated and Technology Division, 619.260.5486; trudolph@sandi.net]

Subject
54. Ratification of License Agreement with Albert Einstein Academies and Service Agreements with Vendors to Provide Temporary Property-Related Services at 446 - 26th Street, San Diego, CA; BUDGETED: YES, PROPOSITION Z AND MEASURE YY FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$357,369.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Proposition Z and Measure YY Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Albert Einstein Academies License and service agreements with vendors to provide temporary property related services at 446 - 26th Street, San Diego, CA, for the period of July 18, 2022, through February 29, 2024.

  1. License Agreement with Albert Einstein Academies for the period of September 1, 2022 – August 31, 2024. (SV23-0430-99 Attachment 1)
  2. Service Agreement with A.O. Reed for the period of July 18, 2022 – February 29, 2024. (SV23-0431-99 Attachment 2)
  3. Service Agreement with Red Rock for the period of July 18, 2022 – February 29, 2024. (SV23-0432-99 Attachment 3)
  4. Service Agreement with 24 Hour Elevator for the period of July 18, 2022 – February 29, 2024. (SV23-0433-99 Attachment 4)

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $357,369.00. Budget Strings:

9381 90405-00-6214-8500-0000-21400-8665 – Proposition Z

9381 90505-00-6214-8500-0000-21500-8665 – Measure YY

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On June 28, 2022, the board approved the Purchase and Sale Agreement (PSA) (Attachment 5) for purchase of one parcel in Sherman Heights for intended long term occupancy of Albert Einstein Academies (AEA).

San Diego Unified (District) became the legal owner of 446 - 26th Street, San Diego, CA (Property) when escrow closed on July 18, 2022. Property is an optimal long-term location for AEA.

Ratification of License Agreement with Albert Einstein Academies and service agreements with vendors to provide temporary property related services at 446 -26th Street, San Diego, CA.

 

  1. License Agreement with Albert Einstein Academies (AEA) to occupy and maintain a portion of the third Floor at their expense. Property is an optimal long-term location for AEA because it is adjacent to AEA Middle School. Term is 24 months, commencing September 1, 2022, through August 31, 2024.
  2. Service Agreement with A.O. Reed to maintain and service the HVAC systems at an estimated cost of $816.00 per quarter, respectively. Term is 18 months, commencing July 18, 2022, through February 29, 2024.
  3. Service Agreement with Red Rock to provide fire alarm monitoring services and maintenance to 446 - 26th Street, San Diego, CA, at a cost of $585.00 per quarter, respectively. Term is 18 months, commencing July 18, 2022, through February 29, 2024.
  4. Service Agreement with 24 Hour Elevator to provide elevator maintenance services to four passenger elevators at a cost of $855.00 per quarter, respectively. Term is 18 months, commencing July 18, 2022, through February 29, 2024.

 

Costs to maintain and operate the property will be offset by license fees and attorning rental income provided by the licensee and existing tenant.

 

Approval of this item will allow the district to continue to temporarily operate and maintain the Property until construction of AEA’s Tenant Improvements begin. Once improvements are completed a long-term lease will be brought to board for approval.  Once lease is in place, AEA will be responsible for operating and maintaining the Property. Upon approval of this item, this location shall be added to the Albert Einstein Academies' charter petition as an additional administrative site.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: Approval of the proposed amendment is subject to the requirements of the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA), Public Resources Code (PRC) section 21000 et. seq., and its implementing Guidelines (California Code of Regulations, Title 14, Division 6, Chapter 3, sections 15300.2 et. seq., as amended). On June 28, 2022, the board approved CEQA findings that the proposed purchase and subsequent operation of facilities for Einstein Charter High School was within the scope of the adopted District Capital Improvement Program Environmental Impact Report, certified by the board on July 27, 2021. The board also directed staff to file a Subsequent Action Notice of Determination for the project with the Recorder/Clerk of San Diego County and the California State Clearinghouse, Office of Planning and Research, which was completed on July 1, 2022. Based on the foregoing, staff has determined that the proposed amendment is consistent with the previously approved project, is consistent with the previously approved CEQA findings, and no further CEQA review is required.

 

[Originator/Contact: Lee Dulgeroff, Chief, Facilities Planning and Construction, 858-637-3516, ldulgeroff@sandi.net, and Gene Fuller, Director, Real Estate, Facilities Planning and Construction, 619.278.6724, gfuller@sandi.net]

Subject
55. Ratification of License Agreement with Empower Language Academy for Additional Classroom Space Beyond Prop 39 Allocation on a Portion of District Property at Twain High School; BUDGETED: YES, REVENUE, PROPERTY MANAGEMENT FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$14,200.20
Budgeted
No
Budget Source
Revenue: Property Management Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify license agreement with Empower Language Academy (Empower) to add classroom space beyond Prop 39 allocation to existing space at Twain High School for one year (Agreement, Attachment 1, PS22-1037-99). The term of the agreement is July 1, 2022, through June 30, 2023.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: $14,200.20; Revenue Budget String: XXXX-04003-00-8699-0000-0000-40003-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The Agreement provides Empower Language Academy the opportunity to add classroom space to their current Prop 39 allocation on a portion of Twain High School for a period of one year only, beginning July 1, 2022, through June 30, 2023, running concurrently with Prop 39 allocation for 2022-23.

 

Empower currently occupies a portion of Twain High School under a Prop 39 allocation in the California Education Code. Empower enrollment does not support additional space beyond their Prop 39 allocation for 2022-23. This Agreement will provide two additional classrooms, for a fee. 

 

As consideration for this agreement, Empower will pay $1,183.35 monthly, due on the first day of each month, beginning July 1, 2022, and payable no later than the first day of each month throughout the term of this agreement.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: Approval of the proposed license agreement is subject to the requirements of the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA), Public Resources Code (PRC) section 21000 et. seq., and its implementing guidelines (California Code of Regulations, Title 14, Division 6, Chapter 3, sections 15300.2 et. seq., as amended). On May 15, 2018, the board adopted the Twain Main Portable Campus Project Negative Declaration (ND), which included construction of 13 portable classrooms, one administration building, and one relocatable restroom at the existing Twain Main High School Campus. The board directed staff to file a CEQA Notice of Determination with the County Recorder/Clerk which occurred on May 16, 2018 (Attachment 2). Under the proposed license agreement, Empower Charter School would occupy existing portable classrooms consistent with the previously approved Twain Main Portable Campus Project. Based on the foregoing, staff has determined that the proposed license agreement is consistent with the previously approved project, was fully analyzed in the referenced ND, and no further CEQA review is required.

 

[Originator/Contact: Lee Dulgeroff, Chief, Facilities Planning and Construction, 858.637.3516, ldulgeroff@sandi.net]

Subject
56. Approval of First Amendments to Agreements with Turpin & Rattan Engineering, Inc., and BSE Engineering, Inc., to Continue Providing Electrical Engineering Services; BUDGETED: YES, PROPOSITIONS S AND Z, MEASURE YY, AND ONGOING AND MAJOR MAINTENANCE FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$350,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
PROPOSITIONS S AND Z, MEASURE YY, AND ONGOING AND MAJOR MAINTENANCE FUNDS

RECOMMENDATIONS: Approve First Amendments to Agreements with Turpin & Rattan Engineering, Inc., and BSE Engineering, Inc., (PS20-0479-11 and PS20-0480-11) to continue providing electrical engineering services. These Amendments increase the consideration and extend the term of the Agreements by two years, for a new term of October 16, 2019 through October 15, 2024.  

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $350,000.00. Budget Strings:

9XXX-9011X-00-6214-8500-0000-21312-8670 – Proposition S

9XXX-9040X-00-6214-8500-0000-21400-8670 – Proposition Z

9XXX-9050X-00-6214-8500-0000-21500-8670 – Measure YY

5686-81500-00-5853-8100-0000-01000-0000 – Ongoing and Major Maintenance Funds

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of July 1, 2021 through June 30, 2022: $135,610.00.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On October 15, 2019, the board approved agreements with Turpin & Rattan Engineering and BSE Engineering to provide on-call Electrical Engineering Services, for an initial term of October 16, 2019 through October 15, 2022, and a total not-to-exceed amount of $600,000.00. These services are required to support Propositions S and Z, and Measure YY for Facilities Planning and Construction (FPC) and Physical Plant Operations (PPO) work.  

 

Along with increasing the consideration and extending the term of the Agreements by two years, these Amendments also update the administration for Invoicing, Fingerprinting Requirements, Labor Compliance requirements, and add Compliance with Applicable Laws, Rules, and Regulations.

 

This First Amendment to Agreement with Turpin & Rattan (PS20-0479-11) increases the compensation by $300,000.00, for a revised total not-to-exceed of $750,000.00.

 

This First Amendment to Agreement with BSE (PS20-0480-11) increases the compensation by $50,000.00, for a revised total not-to-exceed of $200,000.00.  

 

California Government Code section 4525, et seq., grants the district the authority to contract with and employ persons for the furnishing of engineering and environmental services if such persons are specially trained, experienced, and competent to perform the special services requested.

 

[Originator/Contact:  Lee Dulgeroff, Chief, Facilities Planning and Construction, 858.637.3516, ldulgeroff@sandi.net]

57. Approval of Extension of Facility Rental Rate for Use of District-Owned Baseball Fields by the San Diego Adult Baseball League; BUDGETED: YES, REVENUE, CIVIC CENTER RENTAL FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Revenue: Civic Center Rentals Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve extension of the baseball field rental fee of $62.00 flat rate, per day, per field, previously paid by the San Diego Adult Baseball League (SDABL), for baseball field rentals through June 30, 2023. This does not include support staffing fees that may be required at the discretion of the school site administrators.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Revenue to the district will be dependent on use.  Revenue Budget String: XXXX-05100-00-8650-0000-0000-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Established in 1986, SDABL has provided baseball league play and tournaments for adults at fields throughout San Diego County.

 

SDABL has been generous with their time preparing fields for play, as well as contributing financially to baseball programs for students at Canyon Hills High School, Crawford High School, Hoover High School, Mira Mesa High School, and Morse High School.

On May 25, 2021, the board approved a baseball field flat rate fee for the San Diego Adult Baseball League through June 30, 2022.

[Originator/Contact: Lee Dulgeroff, Chief, Facilities Planning and Construction, 858.637.3516, ldulgeroff@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
58. Determine that the Euclid Elementary School Whole Site Modernization Project Has Been Adequately Analyzed by the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Consistency Evaluation Process, as Allowed by Section 15168(c)(2) of the State CEQA Guidelines, and that no Further Environmental Documentation is Required; and Approval of Master Site Lease Agreement and Master Facilities Lease Agreement with Swinerton Builders to Provide Preconstruction Services for the Euclid Elementary School Whole Site Modernization Project (Lease-Leaseback); BUDGETED: YES, MEASURE YY FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$219,530.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Measure YY Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Determine that the Euclid Elementary School Whole Site Modernization Project has been Adequately Analyzed by the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Consistency Evaluation Process, as Allowed by Section 15168(c)(2) of the State CEQA Guidelines, and that no Further Environmental Documentation is Required; and Approve Master Site Lease Agreement and Master Facilities Lease Agreement with Swinerton Builders to Provide Preconstruction Services at Euclid Elementary School (Lease-Leaseback) CC23-0125-23. The term of this Agreement is effective September 13, 2022 and continues until the Project is complete. The preconstruction services for Euclid Elementary School will complete the preconstruction design and Division of the State Architects (DSA) approved plans and specifications and will be bid out to subcontractors by Swinerton Builders. District staff will submit amended Agreements to the Board for the construction of the project, which will include the total guaranteed maximum price (GMP) for the Agreements. All other Terms and conditions will remain the same under the original Agreement.  

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed Preconstruction Services: $219,530.00. Budget String: 9095-90502-00-6230-8500-0000-21500-8640.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: $0.00

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On November 10, 2020, the board adopted a resolution for procedures for evaluating the qualifications of lease-leaseback contractors and the issuance of a request to prequalify for Group F, which are projects at or below $26,000,000.00 in estimated value. On November 12, 2020, the district issued a Request to Prequalify and for Statements of Qualification for Preliminary and Construction Services (RFQ) for Group F Lease-Leaseback Projects.

 

On December 17, 2020, 16 contractors submitted Statements of Qualifications (SOQs) to the district’s RFQ. After evaluating each of the SOQs under the established criteria and procedures, district staff determined that 13 of the contractors met the requirements of the RFQ for Group F Projects. From those 13 qualified contractors, the district issued a subsequent Request for Proposal ("RFP") for Preconstruction Services for the Euclid Elementary School project, utilizing the lease-leaseback delivery method under Education Code section 17406 et seq. The best value criteria for scoring proposals included, but was not limited to, demonstrated competence, relevant experience, compensation, timeliness, and staffing capacity to perform the required work.

 

Sealed proposals to the RFP were due and received on July 28, 2022. The district received a total of four proposals from Balfour Beatty Construction, LLC, Erickson-Hall Construction Company, SOLPAC Construction, Inc., dba Soltek Pacific Construction Company, and Swinerton Builders.

 

Based on the strengths of the proposal submitted, Swinerton Builders has been determined to provide the best value to the district. The remaining three firms were ranked in descending order based upon their proposals. Swinerton Builders is deemed a responsive and responsible proposer for this project, which is located at Euclid Elementary School, 4166 Euclid Avenue, San Diego, CA 92105.

 

Euclid Elementary School is an existing elementary school being modernized for a capacity of 570 students. The Whole Site Modernization includes renovation and reconfiguration of the existing CDC building, which will become the new kindergarten. Special Ed building B will also be reconfigured and renovated along with minor reconfiguration and modernization in the admin and building A and modernization of the auditorium. New grass field, new parking lot with drop-off, and lower grade playground will be constructed once permanent buildings C & K and eleven portable buildings plus one portable restroom building are demolished.

 

On May 10, 2011, the board approved a resolution in support of service-disabled, veterans-owned businesses (SDVOB) and disabled veteran business enterprises (DVBE) which established a three percent required participation of DVBE’s for all district construction contracting opportunities. Once the Division of the State Architects (DSA) approves plans and specifications, Swinerton Builders will bid out the construction portion of the work to subcontractors. District staff will submit amended agreements to the board for the construction of the Project, which will increase the total guaranteed maximum price for the Agreements and include the mandatory DVBE percentage requirement.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: The approval of the Master Site Lease Agreement and Master Facilities Lease Agreement to provide preconstruction services for Euclid Elementary School Whole Site Modernization Project (Proposed Project) is subject to the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA). A Subsequent Document Environmental Checklist (Attachment 1) for the San Diego Unified School District Capital Improvement Program, Final Program EIR (SDUSD CIP Program EIR) was prepared for the Proposed Project, which documents that no new environmental analysis is required, that the Proposed Project is consistent with the certified SDUSD CIP Program EIR, that all applicable SDUSD CIP Program EIR mitigation measures are made conditions of the Proposed Project approval, and that the CEQA obligation of the Proposed Project has been met by the previously certified SDUSD CIP Program EIR.

As described in the attached Subsequent Document Environmental Checklist and the attached CEQA findings in connection with the approval of the Proposed Project (Attachment 2), the Proposed Project is within the scope of the adopted SDUSD CIP Program EIR, certified by the board on July 27, 2021. The certified SDUSD CIP Program EIR was completed in accordance with CEQA and the State CEQA Guidelines. Further, the certified SDUSD CIP Program EIR remains pertinent and continues to have strong informational value. The Proposed Project has undergone a Consistency Determination process in accordance with CEQA Guidelines 15168(c)(2) to determine whether such changes in the project, circumstances, or information would trigger the need for any supplemental environmental documentation based on new or substantially more severe significant environmental impacts. After a thorough factual evaluation, staff has determined that no further supplemental environmental review is required because: 

  1. The Proposed Project is consistent with and within the scope of the SDUSD CIP Program EIR.
  2. The potential environmental impacts of the Proposed Project, including cumulative impacts, were fully considered in the SDUSD CIP Program EIR.
  3. All SDUSD CIP Program EIR mitigation measures applicable to the Project (i.e., all Programmatic Mitigation Measures of the Proposed Project), as identified in the Subsequent Document Environmental Checklist are made a condition of the Proposed Project's approval.
  4. The Proposed Project will not result in environmental effects that were not adequately examined in the SDUSD CIP Program EIR. The Proposed Project will incrementally contribute to, but will not substantially increase the severity of, significant environmental impacts previously identified in the SDUSD CIP Program EIR.
  5. All potentially significant effects on the environment due to the implementation of the Proposed Project have been eliminated or substantially lessened where feasible through SDUSD CIP Program EIR mitigation measures adopted in connection with the Board's approval of the SDUSD CIP Program EIR and incorporated as part of the Proposed Project.
  6. All remaining significant and unavoidable environmental effects of the Proposed Project continue to be acceptable due to the reasons set forth in the SDUSD CIP Program EIR Findings and Statement of Overriding Considerations adopted by the Board in connection with its approval of the SDUSD CIP Program EIR Final EIR, and in the Findings and Statement of Overriding Considerations  adopted by the Board in connection with the approval of the SDUSD CIP Program EIR Final EIR, as referenced and reaffirmed herein.
  7. In accordance with Section 15168(c)(2) of the State CEQA Guidelines, none of the circumstances described in Section 15162(a) of the State CEQA Guidelines is present, and no further environmental review or documentation is required for the Proposed Project.


Approval of the project authorizes staff to file the Finding of Consistency Form (Attachment 3) with the Recorder/County Clerk of San Diego County, California, and Governor’s Office of Planning and Research, State Clearinghouse and Planning Unit and approves the Master Site Lease Agreement and Master Facilities Lease Agreement with Swinerton Builders to provide preconstruction services for the Euclid Elementary School Whole Site Modernization Project.

[Originator/Contact: Lee Dulgeroff, Chief, Facilities Planning and Construction, 858.637.3516, ldulgeroff@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
59. Determine that Clairemont High School Throwing Facilities Improvements Project is Exempt from Further Environmental Review Pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Guidelines Section 15301 – Existing Facilities; and Approval of Agreement with Hamel Contracting, Inc., for Clairemont High School CTE Remodel and Throwing Facilities Improvements; BUDGETED: YES, MEASURE YY FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$2,786,286.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Measure YY Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Determine that Clairemont High School Throwing Facilities Improvements Project is Exempt from Further Environmental Review Pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Guidelines Section 15301 – Existing Facilities; and Approve Agreement with Hamel Contracting, Inc., for Clairemont High School CTE remodel and throwing facilities improvements (CC23-0081-24). The term of the Agreement is September 13, 2022 through the completion of the Project.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount of $2,786,286.00. Budget String: 9332-90502-00-6200-8500-0000-21500-XXXX.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: This project consists of remodeling the CTE and improving the track throwing facilities at Clairemont High School. Specifically, the project includes improvements to the existing shot put and discus throwing facilities including new concrete pads and netting at the discus cage and the construction of a paved accessible path of travel from the existing track field to the shot put and discus areas. The entire field will be removed of weeds and receive a layer of decomposed granite on top of the existing surface. No excavation is required for the implementation of this project.

 

Pursuant to Public Contract Code section 20111(b), the district must publicly competitively bid any public project involving an expenditure of $15,000.00 or more. The notice calling for bids was published once a week for two successive weeks in accordance with Public Contract Code section 20112. Bids were due and opened on August 17, 2022. The district received a total of eight bids from Conan Construction, Inc., De La Fuente Construction, Inc., Hamel Contracting, Inc., M.A. Stevens Construction, Inc., SOLPAC Construction, Inc. dba Soltek Pacific Construction Company, Straight Line General Contractors, Inc., SWCS, Inc., dba Southwest Construction Services, Inc., and Team C Construction. After evaluating the bids, staff determined Hamel Contracting, Inc., to be the lowest responsive and responsible bidder.

 

Additionally, consistent with the May 10, 2011, board-approved resolution in support of service-disabled veteran-owned businesses (SDVOB) and disabled veteran business enterprises (DVBE) which established a three percent required participation of DVBE’s for all district construction contracting opportunities. The recommended contractor, Hamel Contracting, Inc., submitted a 23.5 percent DVBE participation in its bid.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: Approval of the proposed construction agreement for the CTE remodel at Clairemont High School is subject to the requirements of the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA), Public Resources Code (PRC) section 21000 et. seq., and its implementing Guidelines (California Code of Regulations, Title 14, Division 6, Chapter 3, sections 15300.2 et. seq., as amended. On April 26, 2022, the board determined that CTE Projects at Clairemont High School, Hoover High School, and Morse High School were Exempt from CEQA environmental review pursuant to CEQA Guidelines Section 15301 – Existing Facilities and 15314 – Minor Additions to Schools. The board also directed staff to file a Notice of Exemption (NOE) (Attachment 1) for the project with the Recorder/Clerk of San Diego County, which was completed on May 2, 2022. Based on the foregoing, staff has determined that the approval of the proposed agreement for construction of the CTE Project at Clairemont High School is consistent with the previously approved project, was fully analyzed in the referenced NOE, and no further CEQA review is required.

 

The Clairemont High School Throwing Facilities Improvements Project (Proposed Project) is subject to CEQA, however, the project is exempt from further environmental review under CEQA Guidelines Section 15301 – Existing Facilities (Class 1). A Class 1 exemption consists of the operation, repair, maintenance, permitting, leasing, licensing, or minor alteration of existing public or private structures, facilities, mechanical equipment, or topographical features, involving negligible or no expansion of existing or former use. The key consideration is whether the project involves negligible or no expansion of use.

 

As described above, the Proposed Project consists of the renovation to the existing discus and shotput facilities. The Proposed Project would not result in the expansion of these facilities and would not require substantial grading or excavation. Therefore, the application of a Class 1 categorical exemption is appropriate for the Proposed Project.

 

Exceptions to Use of a Categorical Exemption (CEQA Guidelines Section 15300.2): The Proposed Project does not have the potential to trigger any of the exceptions identified in CEQA Guidelines §15300.2 prohibiting the use of a categorical exemption.
 

  1. Location. Classes 3, 4, 5, 6, and 11 are qualified by consideration of where the project is to be located – a project that is ordinarily insignificant in its impact on the environment may in a particularly sensitive environment be significant. Therefore, these classes are considered to apply in all instances, except where the project may impact on an environmental resource of hazardous or critical concern where designated, precisely mapped, and officially adopted pursuant to law by federal, state, or local agencies.
  2. Cumulative Impact. All exemptions for these classes are inapplicable when the cumulative impact of successive projects of the same type in the same place, over time is significant.
  3. Significant Effect. A categorical exemption shall not be used for an activity where there is a reasonable possibility that the activity will have a significant effect on the environment due to unusual circumstances.
  4. Scenic Highways. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project which may result in damage to scenic resources, including but not limited to, trees, historic buildings, rock outcroppings, or similar resources, within a highway officially designated as a state scenic highway. This does not apply to improvements that are required as mitigation by an adopted negative declaration or certified EIR.
  5. Hazardous Waste Sites. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project located on a site that is included on any list compiled pursuant to Section 65962.5 of the Government Code.
  6. Historical Resources. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project that may cause a substantial adverse change in the significance of a historical resource.
     

Environmental Review: The following provides review of the potential environmental issues associated with the Proposed Project to ensure that the above exceptions are not relevant to the project.

 

  1. Location. Construction activities associated with the Proposed Project would be contained to an existing district school site and the existing site use will not change as a result of the implementation of the Proposed Project. The Proposed Project will not impact environmentally sensitive areas or result in a significant impact to an environmental resource of hazardous or critical concern because of existing approved measures between the district and the Department of Toxic Substance Control, described in more detail below under item e. Hazardous Waste Sites. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the Proposed Project.
  2. Cumulative Impact. The Proposed Project is generally considered repair and maintenance of existing facilities, which is consistent with ongoing operations of district sites. Ongoing operations would not be considered a cumulative impact. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the Proposed Project.
  3. Significant Effect. The Proposed Project is not considered an unusual circumstance as these repair and maintenance activities are common activities that occur throughout all district properties. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  4. Scenic Highways. The Proposed Project would not result in the demolition of existing structures or the construction of new facilities that would directly or indirectly affect an officially designated scenic highway or scenic resources near a scenic highway. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  5. Hazardous Waste Sites. According to the Department of Toxic Substance Control (DTSC), no district properties are included on any list compiled pursuant to Section 65962.5 of the Government Code. However, the Proposed Project is within 1,000 feet of a historic burned waste site located underneath the existing main parking area adjacent to Ute Drive, which has been classified as a potential public safety hazard by the DTSC if certain measures are not implemented prior to ground disturbing activities.  

    On December 8, 2016, the DTSC, acting as lead agency under CEQA, prepared and filed a Notice of Exemption (NOE) for a Removal Action Workplan (RAW) for the installation of new hardscape at existing slope and planter in front parking lot of Clairemont High School adjacent to Ute Drive (SCH#: 2016128066). The purpose of the hardscape was to cap an exposed portion of the known burned waste footprint to prevent contact and inhalation of existing hazardous waste by school staff, students, and construction workers, as well as the general public. Project approval by DTSC also required the specific measures to be implemented prior to, during, and after ground disturbing activities including procedures for communications between district staff and regulatory agencies and construction monitoring. Consistent with the previously approved RAW, construction of the Proposed Project, although outside the existing burned waste footprint, would only require notification to the DTSC and the City of San Diego Solid Waste Local Enforcement Agency (LEA) for any excavation activity within 1,000 feet of the known waste footprint and to provide monitoring during construction consistent with the previously approved Community Health and Safety Plan (Attachment 2). However, because no excavation is proposed for this project, notification and monitoring are not required.  

    Because construction of the Proposed Project at Clairemont High School would be required to comply with the existing approved conditions outlined in the RAW, impacts associated with an existing hazardous materials condition would not be exacerbated by the construction of the Proposed Project. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
     
  6. Historical Resources. Historical Resources. According to the CEQA Guidelines regarding historical resources, a substantial adverse change in the significance of a historical resource amounts to a significant impact on the environment (Guidelines § 15064.5(b)). Accordingly, a substantial adverse change means demolition, destruction, relocation, or alteration of the resource or its immediate surroundings resulting in the significance of the resource being materially impaired. Because the Proposed Project does not require the demolition of existing historical era buildings or structures, the significance of a potentially historical resource will not be materially impaired, and no substantial adverse changes to the significance of a historical resource or significant impacts to the environment at the project site is anticipated. Additionally, the likelihood of impacting either prehistoric or historic archeological resources is negligible for the current undertaking due because grading and trenching into native soils is not proposed. This exception does not apply to the project. 
     

Approval of this item approves the Proposed Project as described, authorizes and directs staff to file the attached NOE (Attachment 3) with the San Diego County Recorder/Clerk, and approves the agreement as described above.

 

[Originator/Contact: Lee Dulgeroff, Chief, Facilities Planning and Construction, 858.637.3516, ldulgeroff@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
60. Determine that the Roof Replacement Project at Horton Elementary School is Exempt from Further Environmental Review Pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Guidelines Sections 15301 – Existing Facilities; and Approval of Agreement with A. Preman Roofing, Inc., for Re-Roofing and Beam Repair at Horton Elementary School; BUDGETED: YES, MEASURE YY FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$1,854,366.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Measure YY Funds

RECOMMENDATIONS: Determine that the Roof Replacement Project at Horton Elementary School is Exempt from Further Environmental Review Pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Guidelines Sections 15301 – Existing Facilities; and Approve Agreement with A. Preman Roofing, Inc., for re-roofing and beam repair at Horton Elementary School (CC23-0233-39). The term of the Agreement is September 14, 2022 through the completion of the Project.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount of $1,854,366.00. Budget String: 9149-90502-00-6200-8500-0000-21500-8640.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: This project consists of replacement of roofs on three permanent buildings (kindergarten / assembly / administration / classrooms) and beam repair at Horton Elementary School. Re-roofing consists of the following:

  • Remove abandoned rooftop mechanical equipment, infill openings.
  • Demo existing gravel built-up roofing and replace with single ply (PVC) roofing.
  • Remove and replace existing edge metal and select flashing in preparation of new roofing installation.
  • Remove mechanical plumbing and electrical items required for new roofing installation, and replace in kind as instructed.
  • Remove protect and reinstall (E) PV panels in kind.

 

Pursuant to Public Contract Code section 20111(b), the district must publicly competitively bid any public project involving an expenditure of $15,000.00 or more. The notice calling for bids was published once a week for two successive weeks in accordance with Public Contract Code section 20112. Bids were due and opened on August 18, 2022. The district received a total of two bids from A. Preman Roofing, Inc., and Chambers, Inc., dba Roof Construction. After evaluating the bids, staff determined A. Preman Roofing, Inc., to be the lower responsive and responsible bidder.

 

Additionally, consistent with the May 10, 2011, board-approved resolution in support of service-disabled veteran-owned businesses (SDVOB) and disabled veteran business enterprises (DVBE) which established a three percent required participation of DVBE’s for all district construction contracting opportunities. The recommended contractor, A. Preman Roofing, Inc., submitted a three percent DVBE participation in its bid.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: The proposed activity is a project subject to the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA), however, it is exempt from further environmental review under CEQA Guidelines Sections. Class 1 consists of the operation, repair, maintenance, permitting, leasing, licensing, or minor alteration of existing public or private structures, facilities, mechanical equipment, or topographical features, involving negligible or no expansion of existing or former use. (CEQA Guidelines §15301]). The Proposed Project involves roof repairs to an existing school facility. Therefore, the application of a Class 1 categorical exemption is appropriate for the Project.

 

Exceptions to Use of a Categorical Exemption (CEQA Guidelines Section 15300.2): Section 15300.2 of the State CEQA Guidelines specifies several exceptions to the use of a categorical exemption.

  • Location. Classes 3, 4, 5, 6, and 11 are qualified by consideration of where the Project is to be located – a Project that is ordinarily insignificant in its impact on the environment may, in a particularly sensitive environment, be significant, therefore, these classes are considered to apply in all instances, except where the Project may impact on an environmental resource of hazardous or critical concern where designated, precisely mapped, and officially adopted pursuant to law by federal, state, or local agencies. The Proposed Project does not fall within this class of exemption. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Cumulative Impact. All exemptions for these classes are inapplicable when the cumulative impact of successive projects of the same type in the same place, over time is significant. The Proposed Project consists of repairs to existing facilities and would not result in cumulative construction impacts because no ongoing projects would occur at the same time as the construction of the Proposed Project. Operational cumulative impacts would not occur because no operational changes are proposed. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Significant Effect. A categorical exemption shall not be used for an activity where there is a reasonable possibility that the activity will have a significant effect on the environment due to unusual circumstances. The Proposed Project consists of repairs to existing facilities where no changes in use would occur. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Scenic Highways. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project which may result in damage to scenic resources, including but not limited to, trees, historic buildings, rock outcroppings, or similar resources, within a highway officially designated as a state scenic highway. There are no exterior physical improvements associated with the Proposed Project that would result in new visual impacts to scenic highways. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Hazardous Waste Sites. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project located on a site that is included on any list compiled pursuant to Section 65962.5 of the Government Code. There are no physical improvements associated with the Proposed Project that would result in new hazardous materials impacts. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Historical Resources. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project that may cause a substantial adverse change in the significance of a historical resource. The replacement of existing roofing material at Horton Elementary School would not result in significant impacts to existing historical resources as the existing affected rooftops have been heavily modified with HVAC and Solar Power Generation Equipment. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.

 

Approval of this item approves the Proposed Project as described, authorizes and directs staff to file the attached Notice of Exemption with the San Diego County Recorder/Clerk, and approves the agreement as described above.

 

[Originator/Contact: Lee Dulgeroff, Chief, Facilities Planning and Construction, 858.637.3516, ldulgeroff@sandi.net]
