Sep 6, 2022 11:54 AM :: Approved by George Harris. Routed to Lee Dulgeroff for approval.
Sep 6, 2022 2:15 PM :: Approved by Lee Dulgeroff. Routed to Jodie Macalos for approval.
Sep 6, 2022 5:32 PM :: Approved by Jodie Macalos. Routed to Drew Rowlands for approval.
Sep 7, 2022 11:08 AM :: Final approval by Drew Rowlands
I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
61. Determine that the Roof Replacement Project at the San Diego School of Creative and Performing Arts (SDSCPA) is Exempt from Further Environmental Review Pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Guidelines Sections 15301 – Existing Facilities; Approval of Agreement with A. Preman Roofing, Inc., to Provide Roof Replacement and Repair Building 600 Wall at the San Diego School of Creative and Performing Arts (SDSCPA); BUDGETED: YES, PROPOSITION Z FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$2,263,340.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Proposition Z Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Determine that the roof replacement project at the San Diego School of Creative and Performing Arts (SDSCPA) is exempt from further environmental review pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) guidelines section 15301 – Existing Facilities; and Approve Agreement with A. Preman Roofing, Inc., to provide roof replacement and repair building 600 wall at the San Diego School of Creative and Performing Arts (SDSCPA) (CC23-0212-32). The term of this Agreement is September 14, 2022 through completion of the project.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $2,263,340.00.  Budget String: 9368-90405-00-6200-8500-0000-21400-8640.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The project generally consists of roof replacement and repair of building 600 Wall at the San Diego School of Creative and Performing Arts at 2425 Dusk Drive, San Diego, CA 92139.

 

Pursuant to Public Contract Code Section 20111(b), the district must publicly competitively bid any public project involving an expenditure of $15,000.00 or more. The notice calling for bids was published once a week for two successive weeks in accordance with Public Contract Code section 20112. Bids were due and opened on August 11, 2022. The district received a total of three bids from A. Preman Roofing, Inc., Chambers, Inc., dba Roof Construction, and Sylvester Roofing. After evaluating the bids, staff determined A. Preman Roofing to be the lowest responsive and responsible bidder.

 

Additionally, consistent with the May 10, 2011 board approved resolution in support of service-disabled veteran-owned businesses (SDVOB) and disabled veteran business enterprises (DVBE), which established a three percent required participation of DVBEs for all district construction contracting opportunities, the recommended contractor, A. Preman Roofing, Inc., submitted a three percent DVBE participation in its bid.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: The proposed activity is a project subject to the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA), however, it is exempt from further environmental review under CEQA Guidelines Sections. Class 1 consists of the operation, repair, maintenance, permitting, leasing, licensing, or minor alteration of existing public or private structures, facilities, mechanical equipment, or topographical features, involving negligible or no expansion of existing or former use. (CEQA Guidelines §15301]). The Proposed Project involves roof repairs to an existing school facility. Therefore, the application of a Class 1 categorical exemption is appropriate for the Project.

 

Exceptions to Use of a Categorical Exemption (CEQA Guidelines Section 15300.2): Section 15300.2 of the State CEQA Guidelines specifies several exceptions to the use of a categorical exemption.

 

  • Location. Classes 3, 4, 5, 6, and 11 are qualified by consideration of where the Project is to be located – a Project that is ordinarily insignificant in its impact on the environment may, in a particularly sensitive environment, be significant, therefore, these classes are considered to apply in all instances, except where the Project may impact on an environmental resource of hazardous or critical concern where designated, precisely mapped, and officially adopted pursuant to law by federal, state, or local agencies. The Proposed Project does not fall within this class of exemption. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Cumulative Impact. All exemptions for these classes are inapplicable when the cumulative impact of successive projects of the same type in the same place, over time is significant. The Proposed Project consists of repairs to existing facilities and would not result in cumulative construction impacts because no ongoing projects would occur at the same time as the construction of the Proposed Project. Operational cumulative impacts would not occur because no operational changes are proposed. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Significant Effect. A categorical exemption shall not be used for an activity where there is a reasonable possibility that the activity will have a significant effect on the environment due to unusual circumstances. The Proposed Project consists of repairs to existing facilities where no changes in use would occur. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Scenic Highways. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project which may result in damage to scenic resources, including but not limited to, trees, historic buildings, rock outcroppings, or similar resources, within a highway officially designated as a state scenic highway. There are no exterior physical improvements associated with the Proposed Project that would result in new impacts to scenic highways. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Hazardous Waste Sites. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project located on a site that is included on any list compiled pursuant to Section 65962.5 of the Government Code. There are no physical improvements associated with the Proposed Project that would result in new hazardous materials impacts. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Historical Resources. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project that may cause a substantial adverse change in the significance of a historical resource. There are no physical improvements associated with the Proposed Project that would result in impacts to existing historical resources. SDSCPA was built in 1992 and not considered a historic resource. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.

 

Approval of this item approves the Proposed Project as described, authorizes and directs staff to file the attached Notice of Exemption with the San Diego County Recorder/Clerk, and approves the agreement as described above.

 

[Originator/Contact: Lee Dulgeroff, Chief, Facilities Planning and Construction, 858.637.3516, ldulgeroff@sandi.net]

Subject
62. Authorize the Use of State Department of General Services California Multiple Award Schedule (CMAS) Contract with Anixter, Inc., to Continue Providing Locking Hardware; BUDGETED: YES, ONGOING AND MAJOR MAINTENANCE FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$2,000,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Ongoing and Major Maintenance Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Authorize the purchase of Locking Hardware pursuant to the California Multiple Award Schedule (CMAS) contract with Anixter, Inc.,(4-22-05-1011; GD23-0306-30) from September 14, 2022 to September 13, 2025. Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to complete the purchase(s).  The term of the CMAS contract is May 5, 2022 through April 27, 2027. 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount for the initial term: $2,000,000.00. Budget String: 5686-81500-00-9321-8100-0000-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of April 18, 2021 through April 17, 2022: $278,418.88.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: This Authorization will allow the district to purchase locking hardware in support of the Physical Plant Operations Department through September 13, 2025. 

 

Public Contract Code (PCC) § 10290 et seq. and 12101.5 include approval for local government agencies to use Department of General Services California Multiple Award Schedules (CMAS) for acquisition of information technology and non-information technology products and services. Public Contract Code (PCC) §§ 10298 and 10299 authorize local government agencies and school districts to use CMAS and other Department of General Services (DGS) agreements without competitive bidding. However, each local government agency should make its own determination whether the CMAS program is consistent with their procurement policies and regulations.

 

CMAS agreements are established for products and services that have been competitively assessed, negotiated, or bid primarily by the federal General Services Administration (GSA).  The awarded CMAS contract is structured to comply with California procurement codes, guidelines, and policies, and provide for the highest level of contractual protection. A CMAS is not established through a competitive bid process conducted by the State of California. It is because of this that all pricing, products and/or services offered must have been previously bid and awarded on a GSA multiple award schedule. However, the state does not use the GSA award schedule.  Instead, the CMAS Unit establishes a totally independent California agreement for the same products and services at equal or lower prices.

 

Services not available on the CMAS program include most professional services (legal services, financial audits, engineering, etc.) and public works (Public Contract Code (PCC) § 1101).  Also excluded from CMAS purchasing are Facility Planning services, Registered Nursing services, and Security Guard services (by CMAS Policy).

 

The term of the CMAS contract is from May 5, 2022 to April 27, 2027.  Terms and conditions as well as the schedule are included via links in the attached contract.  District staff has determined that: 1) the purchase of locking hardware is an authorized purchase under the CMAS contract; 2) the district will obtain locking hardware at lower prices through the CMAS contract than could be obtained by competitive bidding or other applicable purchasing processes; 3) the district is authorized to purchase locking hardware from the CMAS contract from September 14, 2022 until September 13, 2025; and 4) that purchasing through this CMAS contract is in the best interest of the district.

 

[Originator/Contact: John Hensley, Director, Physical Plant Operations, Office of the Chief of Operations Officer, 858.627.1751, jhensley@sandi.net]

63. Ratification of Physical Plant Operations Change Orders for the Period of January 2019 - March 2022; BUDGETED: YES, PROPOSITION Z, MEASURE YY, ONGOING AND MAJOR MAINTENANCE, AND PPO CAPITAL PROJECTS FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
($603,253.16)
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Proposition Z, Measure YY, Ongoing and Major Maintenance, and PPO Capital Projects Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify individual change orders approved by the Chief Operations Officer, in accordance with delegated authority, for the period of January 1, 2019 through March 31, 2022. The exhibit reflects changes that have been approved for implementation and/or payment or credit back to District and are submitted for ratification by the Board of Education.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total credit of ($603,253.16) for the period of January 1, 2019 through March 31, 2022.

Budget Strings:

9XXX-90404-00-5751-8500-0000-21400-5640 (Proposition Z, Ongoing and Major Maintenance Funds)

Because of certain deductive change orders in which money is issued back to the district as a credit, the cumulative change order rate for the program during this period was -7.29 percent.

Subject
64. Approval of Agreement with Procure America, Inc., to Provide the District with Continued SDG&E Power Utility Review for Electricity Only to Identify Potential Savings; BUDGETED: YES, UTILITIES MANAGEMENT FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$1,000,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Utilities Management Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreement with Procure America, Inc., to provide the district with continued SDG&E power utility review for electricity only to identify potential savings (PS23-0203-30). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is November 1, 2022 through October 31, 2027.

 

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount of $1,000,000.00, during the five-year term of the Agreement. Budget String: 5537-00000-00-5100-8100-0000-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Procure America, Inc., will continue to perform a review of the district's utility services for electricity only to identify potential savings. The district's utility services are funded through the general fund and this effort may result in future general fund savings. An Enterprise Strategic Plan (ESP) report will summarize the results and provide a thorough explanation of legal grounds for cost reduction and/or refund opportunities on a quarterly basis. This is a future contingency fee agreement, and the ESP pre-reviews are at no cost to the district. If Procure America, Inc., identifies potential opportunities that yield savings and if the district chooses to implement the changes, all revenue will be paid 30 percent of actual savings during the contract term. At end of term there will be no further entitlement to revenue regardless of initiation date. The district may terminate for convenience at any time during the term.

 

 

[Originator/Contact: John Hensley, Director, Physical Plant Operations, Office of the Chief of Operations Officer, 858.627.7127; jhensley@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
65. Authorization to Utilize the City of La Mesa's Agreement with Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., for the Procurement of Type B Asphalt Concrete; BUDGETED: YES, ONGOING AND MAJOR MAINTENANCE FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$200,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Ongoing and Major Maintenance Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Authorize utilization of the City of La Mesa's Agreement with Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., for the procurement of Type B Asphalt Concrete (Resolution No. 2022-090/Bid 19-19) (GD23-0404-30). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is one year with two option years to renew from September 14, 2022 through September 13, 2025.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $200,000.00. Budget String: 5686-81500-00-4315-8100-0000-01000-0000. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of July 1, 2021, through June 30, 2022: $79,945.70.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: On May 5, 2022, the district participated in the bidding process with the Cities of Carlsbad, Chula Vista, El Cajon, National City, San Marcos, Santee, and the San Dieguito Water District, with the City of La Mesa being the lead agency. On August 9, 2022, the City of La Mesa passed Resolution No. 2022-090 awarding the bid and four one-year options to renew to Martin Marietta Materials, Inc. 

 

 

Pursuant to Public Contract Code Section 20118, school districts may, without further competitive bidding, use contracts awarded by other public agencies where such contracts are bid in accordance with the California Public Contract Code and the board finds that it is in the best interest of the district to use the publicly bid contract. By approving this item, the board finds that use of the City of La Mesa contract is in the best interest of the district.

 

 

[Originator/Contact: John Hensley, Director, Physical Plant Operations, Office of the Chief Operations Officer, 858.627.1751, jhensley@sandi.net]

La Mesa City Council Resolution 2022-090.pdf (448 KB)

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
66. Approval of Agreement with Blue Coast Consulting to Provide Non-DSA Project Inspection Services; BUDGETED: YES; MEASURE YY AND ONGOING AND MAJOR MAINTENANCE FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$300,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
MEASURE YY AND ONGOING AND MAJOR MAINTENANCE FUNDS

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreement with Blue Coast Consulting to provide non-DSA project inspection services (PS23-0230-40).  The term of this Agreement is September 14, 2022 through June 30, 2024.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $300,000.00. Budget Strings: 9xxx-90504-00-5751-8500-0000-21500-86XX (Measure YY) and 5686-81500-00-5100-8100-0000-01000-0000 (Ongoing & Major Maintenance Funds).

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND:  On February 25, 2020, the board approved a change in the district’s lead levels in the drinking water policy that included replacing drinking fountains with ADA compliant filtered Hydration Stations (combination drinking fountain/bottle filling stations). 

 

This policy requires the removal of existing drinking fountains and the installation of approximately 2,000 Hydration Stations across the district.  Hydration Stations will be incorporated into new building construction and whole-site modernization projects.

 

This Agreement is for the professional service to inspect the installation of Hydration Stations throughout the district, identify any issues with the installations, and provide daily reports on the installation progress.  This is in support of the board’s action to provide the district with the best water possible.

California Government Code 53060 grants the district the authority to contract with and employ persons to furnish special services if such persons are specially trained, experienced, and competent to perform the special services required.

 

[Originator/Contact:  John Hensley, Director, Physical Plant Operations, Office of the Chief Operations Officer, 858.627.7171, jhensley@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
67. Determine that the Installation of Hydration Stations at Eight Sites is Exempt from Further Environmental Review Pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Guidelines Sections 15301 – Existing Facilities; Approval of Agreement with M.A. Stevens Construction, Inc., to Furnish and Install Hydration Stations at Eight Sites Group 1; BUDGETED: YES, MEASURE YY FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$1,139,456.80
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Measure YY Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Determine that the installation of hydration stations at eight sites is exempt from further environmental review pursuant to California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) guidelines section 15301 – Existing Facilities; and Approve Agreement with M.A. Stevens Construction, Inc., to furnish and install hydration stations at Bay Point Preschool, Cabrillo, Dewey, Loma Portal, Ocean Beach, and Silver Gate Elementary Schools, Dana Middle School, and Point Loma High School (CP23-0216-24). The term of the Agreement is September 13, 2022, through the completion of the project.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount of $1,139,456.80. Budget String: XXXX-90502-00-5751-8500-0000-21500-8613.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: This project consists of furnishing and installing hydration stations at Bay Point Preschool, Cabrillo, Dewey, Loma Portal, Ocean Beach, and Silver Gate Elementary Schools, Dana Middle School, and Point Loma High School.

 

Pursuant to Public Contract Code section 20111(b), the district must publicly competitively bid any public project involving an expenditure of $15,000.00 or more. The notice calling for bids was published once a week for two successive weeks in accordance with Public Contract Code section 20112. Bids were due and opened on August 4, 2022. The district received a total of three bids from Ahrens Mechanical, Blue Pacific Engineering Construction, Inc., and M.A. Stevens Construction, Inc. After evaluating the bids, staff determined M. A. Stevens Construction, Inc., to be the lowest responsive and responsible bidder.

 

Additionally, consistent with the May 10, 2011, board-approved resolution in support of service-disabled veteran-owned businesses (SDVOB) and disabled veteran business enterprises (DVBE) which established a three percent required participation of DVBE’s for all district construction contracting opportunities. The recommended contractor, M. A. Stevens Construction, Inc., submitted a three percent DVBE participation in its bid.

 

CEQA ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW: Approval of the Proposed Project is subject to CEQA, however, it is exempt from further environmental review under CEQA Guidelines Sections 15301 (Class 1) – Existing Facilities. Class 1 consists of the operation, repair, maintenance, permitting, leasing, licensing, or minor alteration of existing public or private structures, facilities, mechanical equipment, or topographical features, involving negligible or no expansion of existing or former use. The key consideration is whether the project involves negligible or no expansion of an existing use. Examples cited by the CEQA guidelines relevant to the Proposed Project include interior or exterior alterations including interior partitions, plumbing, and electrical conveyances. The Proposed Project falls under the definition of exterior alterations and plumbing. 

 

Exceptions to Use of a Categorical Exemption (CEQA Guidelines Section 15300.2): Section 15300.2 of the State CEQA Guidelines specifies several exceptions to the use of a categorical exemption.

  • Location. Classes 3, 4, 5, 6, and 11 are qualified by consideration of where the Project is to be located – a Project that is ordinarily insignificant in its impact on the environment may, in a particularly sensitive environment, be significant, therefore, these classes are considered to apply in all instances, except where the Project may impact on an environmental resource of hazardous or critical concern where designated, precisely mapped, and officially adopted pursuant to law by federal, state, or local agencies. The Proposed Project does not fall within this class of exemption. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Cumulative Impact. All exemptions for these classes are inapplicable when the cumulative impact of successive projects of the same type in the same place, over time is significant. The Proposed Project consists of upgrades to existing facilities and would not result in cumulative impacts because no ongoing projects would occur at the same time as the construction of the Proposed Project. Operational cumulative impacts would not occur because no operational changes are proposed. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Significant Effect. A categorical exemption shall not be used for an activity where there is a reasonable possibility that the activity will have a significant effect on the environment due to unusual circumstances. The Proposed Project consists of upgrades to existing facilities where no changes in use would occur. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Scenic Highways. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project which may result in damage to scenic resources, including but not limited to, trees, historic buildings, rock outcroppings, or similar resources, within a highway officially designated as a state scenic highway. There are no exterior physical improvements associated with the Proposed Project that would result in new impacts to scenic highways. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Hazardous Waste Sites. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project located on a site that is included on any list compiled pursuant to Section 65962.5 of the Government Code. There are no physical improvements associated with the Proposed Project that would result in new hazardous materials impacts. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.
  • Historical Resources. A categorical exemption shall not be used for a project that may cause a substantial adverse change in the significance of a historical resource. There are no physical improvements associated with the Proposed Project that would result in impacts to existing historical resources. Therefore, this exception does not apply to the project.

Approval of this item approves the Proposed Project as described, authorizes and directs staff to file the attached Notice of Exemption with the San Diego County Recorder/Clerk, and approves the agreement as described above.

[Originator/Contact: John Hensley, Director, Physical Plant Operations, Office of the Chief Operations Officer, 858.627.7151, jhensley@sandi.net]

68. Authorization to Utilize the State of California Multiple Award Schedule (CMAS) Contract 1-22-23-20F to Purchase Four Ford Electric F150 Trucks; BUDGETED: YES, CALIFORNIA AIR RESOURCES BOARD GRANT FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$228,182.52
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
California Air Resources Board Grant Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Authorize Utilization of the State of California Multiple Award Schedule (CMAS) Contract 1-22-23-20F to Purchase four Ford 150 Electric Trucks from Downtown Ford (GD23-0445-03). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this authorization. The term of this authorization is September 14, 2022 through September 13, 2023.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $228,182.52. Budget String: 5650-78555-00-6495-3600-0000-01000-7790. Purchase Orders issued for vehicles purchased through the CMAS contract 1-22-23-20F will be brought forward for board approval on a monthly purchase order report.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The district’s fleet of Physical Plant Operations (PPO) trucks includes trucks are over 20 years old. Trucks purchased under this Agreement will replace these trucks and be used by the Landscape Department to service our schools and administration sites within the Lincoln Cluster of schools. The new trucks will replace aged trucks which are having difficulty meeting the state’s current smog emission requirements. The new trucks will be more fuel efficient and environmentally friendly. All funding will come from the CARB Grant “Clean Mobility in Schools PilotGrant” # G18-CMIS-02.

 

[Originator/Contact: Gene Robinson, Director, Transportation and Distribution, Office of the Operations Support Officer, 858.496.8710, grobinson@sandi.net]

69. Approval of Agreement with Electric Vehicle Conversion, LLC, dba EVC for the Purchase of Two Electric Trucks; BUDGETED: YES, CALIFORNIA AIR RESOURCES BOARD GRANT FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$399,778.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
California Air Resources Board Grant Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve the Agreement with Electric Vehicle Conversion, LLC, dba EVC for the purchase of Two Electric Trucks (GD22-1140-03). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this authorization. The term of this authorization is September 14, 2022, through September 13, 2023.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $399,778.00. Budget String: 5650-78555-00-6495-3600-0000-01000-7790.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The Strategic Sourcing and Contracts Department advertised bid No. GD22-1140-03 on June 16 and June 23, 2022 to competitively solicit bids for the purchase of two electric trucks. On July 6, 2022, a public bid opening was conducted. There were two bidders: Electric Vehicle Conversion dba EV and Motive Power Systems. Of the two responsible and responsive bidders Electric Vehicle Conversion dba EVC had the lowest price.  Recommendation of award to Electric Vehicle Conversion dba EVC.

 

These Specialty Vehicles are a new type of vehicle for the district; one will be equipped as an all electric Food Truck with the capability to prepare and serve meals at remote locations throughout the district, primarily in the Lincoln Cluster. The second vehicle will be equipped as a Community Outreach/Emergency Response vehicle to be use primarily by School Police staff. These vehicles will enhance services provided to students and community districtwide. The new trucks will be all electric requiring less maintenance as well as being environmentally friendly. All funding will come from the CARB (California Air Resources Board) Grant “Clean Mobility in Schools Pilot Grant” # G18-CMIS-02.

 

[Originator/Contact: Gene Robinson, Director, Transportation, and Distribution Services, Office of the Operations Support Officer, 858.496.8710, grobinson@sandi.net]

70. Ratification of Agreement with The Regents of the University of California on Behalf of UC San Diego and Preuss Charter School to Continue Providing Home-to-School Bus Transportation Service for Preuss Charter School Students; BUDGETED: YES, REVENUE, UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA SAN DIEGO FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$388,542.75
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Revenue: University of California San Diego Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratification of Agreement with The Regents of the University of California on behalf of UC San Diego and Preuss Charter School to continue providing home-to-school bus transportation bus service for Preuss Charter School students (SV23-0327-03). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate the execution of this Agreement and subsequent option years if granted by Preuss to district. The term of this Agreement is August 8, 2022 through June 16, 2023, with four additional one-year options to renew.     

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed revenue: $388,542.75 for each annual term of the Agreement.  Revenue Budget String: 5650-09974-00-5730-3600-0000-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of July 1, 2021 through June 30, 2022: $1,952,850.64.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Preuss Charter School is a California Public Charter School organized pursuant to Education Code section 47600 et seq., and specifically operates as a public benefit, non-profit corporation. Preuss requires public "Home-to-School" bus transportation services be provided to transport its charter school students. Preuss Charter School has optioned to enter into a direct negotiated contract with the district to continue providing pupil transportation services.

 

In 2015, the district entered into an agreement (SV-14-0712-21) with The Regents of the University of California on Behalf of UC San Diego and Preuss Charter School. 

 

The district and UC San Diego are entering into a new agreement (SV23-0327-03) to continue providing home-to-school bus transportation services for Preuss Charter School students.

 

[Originator/Contact: Gene Robinson, Director, Transportation and Distribution Services, Office of the Operations Support Officer, 858.496.8710, grobinson@sandi.net]

71. FISCAL IMPACT: Routine Maintenance, Service and Repair, Construction Services, and Purchase Order Agreements: $199,494.53; Purchase Orders less than $99,100.00, purchases due to COVID-19, and Purchase Orders greater than $99,100 for instructional materials: $11,293,112.17, for a total expense of $11,492,606.70.  Budget String: Various Site Identified Funds.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of July 1, 2021 through July 31, 2021: $34,821,954.77.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: These transactions are submitted to the board for review pursuant to Education Code sections 17604 and 17605 and under its delegation of authority to the district's Director, Purchasing and Contracts.  To allow for efficiency in the administration of a large urban school district, California Education Code section 17605 specifically allows a school district to delegate limited purchasing power, i.e., for purchases no greater than $99,100.00 (for the year 2022) for supplies, materials, apparatus, equipment, non-construction services not greater than $99,100.00, and construction services less than $15,000.00.  For this reason, these types of transactions must be reviewed by the board within 60 days of the date of the transaction under Education Code section 17605.  Supplementary instructional materials (e.g., textbooks) may be purchased by the school district for any amount pursuant to Public Contract Code section 20118.3.  Pursuant to the authority delegated to the San Diego Unified School District Director, Purchasing and Contracts, on June 28, 2022, these purchase orders have been released to the respective vendors and are being submitted for review by the board at this time.  Additionally, the attached agreements were signed pursuant to the delegation of authority and, as required by Education Code section 17604, must be approved or ratified by the Board of Education. The district has met the requirements of Education Code sections 17604 and 17605 with this process of reporting out the specified purchase orders under $99,100.00 (for the year 2022) that are not associated with any previously-approved board contracts and the ratification of contracts signed under delegation of authority.

 

[Originator/Contact: Linda Hippe, Director (TOC), Purchasing and Contracts, Office of the Chief Operations Officer, 858.522.5808, lhippe@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
72. Approval of Agreement with Charity Apostolic Church to Provide the “No Shots Fired” Program which Focuses on Gang Prevention, Intervention, and Outreach Through Individual and Group Mentoring for Students Who Are At-Risk for Gang Involvement; BUDGETED: N/A
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
No
Budgeted
No
Budget Source
Not Applicable

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreement with Charity Apostolic Church to provide the “No Shots Fired” program which focuses on gang prevention, intervention and outreach through individual and group mentoring for students who are at risk of gang involvement. (PS23-0032-89). Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is September 14, 2022 through June 30, 2023.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Charity Apostolic Church will provide "No Shots Fired (NSF)," a violence interdiction program with a focus on primary gun violence prevention, core intervention, tertiary deterrence, and hospital based violence intervention and injury reduction. The program detects and interrupts planned violent activity, facilitates behavior change of high-risk individuals, and changes community norms. Qualified and trained mentors will advocate for, guide, and provide support and mentorships to those enrolled in the life mapping program. These individuals will be engaged every day by different partners in the community, have one-on-one meetings with potential home visits, providing service in the community, and be introduced to dozens of resources throughout San Diego County.

 

[Originator/Contact:  Nicole DeWitt, Executive Director, Leadership and Learning, 619.508.6632, ndewitt@sandi.net]

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount for General Service Agreements $101,478.00; Budget String: Various School Site Identified Funds.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: Not applicable.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: These transactions are submitted to the board for review pursuant to Education Code sections 17604 and 17605 and under its delegation of authority to the district Director, Purchasing and Contracts. To allow for efficiency in the administration of a large urban school district, California Education Code section 17605 specifically allows a school district to delegate limited purchasing power, i.e., for purchases no greater than $99,100.00 for the 2022 calendar year. This bid threshold is adjusted annually in accordance with the Public Contract Code section 20111.

 

Originator/Contact: Linda Hippe, (TOC) Director, Purchasing and Contracts (TOC), Office of the Chief Operations Officer, 858.522.5808, lhippe@sandi.net]

Subject
74. Approval of Agreements with the California Energy Commission to Accept CalSHAPE Grant Funds; BUDGETED: YES, REVENUE, CALIFORNIA ENERGY COMMISSION GRANT FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$4,552,770.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Revenue: California Energy Commission Grant Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreements with the California Energy Commission to Accept CalSHAPE Grant Funds for the benefit of multiple district schools.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Receive $4,552,770.00 in grant funds. Revenue Budget Strings:  0000-78800-00-8590-0000-0000-01000-0000 and 0000-78801-00-8590-0000-0000-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The district applied for and was awarded two California Schools Healthy Air, Plumbing, and Efficiency (CalSHAPE) Ventilation Program grants from the California Energy Commission (CEC). CalSHAPE is funded by the School Energy Efficiency Stimulus Program, established by Assembly Bill 841 (Ting, Chapter 372, Statutes of 2020), which in part provides grants to assess, maintain, adjust, repair, or upgrade heating, ventilation, and air conditioning systems. Funds will be used to improve ventilation systems at multiple schools listed below.

 

Adams Elementary

Balboa Elementary

Chollas/Mead Elementary

Clay Elementary

Dewey Elementary

Edison Elementary

Encanto Elementary

Garfield High

Hamilton Elementary

Hardy Elementary

Horton Elementary

Knox Middle

Logan Memorial Educational Campus

Montgomery Middle

Ralph Waldo Emerson Elementary

Rosa Parks Elementary

Ross Elementary

Webster Elementary

Whittier K-12

Wilson Middle

ALBA 

Audubon K-8 

Bell Middle 

Burbank Elementary 

Cherokee Point Elementary 

Fay Elementary 

Freese Elementary 

Golden Hill K-8 

Ibarra Elementary 

Johnson Elementary 

Joyner Elementary 

Lincoln High 

Normal Heights Elementary 

Penn Elementary 

Porter Elementary 

Rodriguez Elementary 

Sherman Elementary 

Zamorano Elementary

 

 

[Originator/Contact:  Ron Rode, Director, Research and Evaluation, Integrated Technology Division, 619.725.7190, rrode@sandi.net]

Subject
75. Approval of Agreement with the Board of School Commissioners of Mobile County to Accept Grant Funds for a JROTC STEM Leadership Academy; BUDGETED: YES, REVENUE, BOARD OF SCHOOL COMMISSIONERS OF MOBILE COUNTY GRANT FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$453,550.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Revenue: Board of School Commissioners of Mobile County Grant Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve Agreement with the Board of School Commissioners of Mobile County to Accept Grant Funds for a JROTC STEM Leadership Academy. The term of the Agreement is September 15, 2022 to September 14, 2025.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Receive $453,550.00 in grant funds. Revenue Budget String: 0000-58403-00-8287-0000-0000-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: The district applied for and was awarded a grant from the Board of School Commissioners of Mobile County to provide a JROTC STEM Leadership Academy. Grant funds will be used to replicate a the JROTC STEM Leadership Academy model (STEM Academy), for the district's JROTC program, and shall provide staff; college/university host site; materials and equipment; and other expenses required to implement the STEM Academy. The STEM Academy will take place each summer from 2023 to 2025, inclusively, with grant funds supporting approximately 120 JROTC Cadets recruited from San Diego Unified School District and one STEM Instructional Team for every 20-25 Cadets. 

 

 

 

 

[Originator/Contact:  Ron Rode, Director, Research and Evaluation, Integrated Technology Division, 619.725.7190, rrode@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
76. Ratification of Agreement with the County of San Diego to Accept K-12 Community Grant Program Funds for Hamilton Elementary School; BUDGETED: YES, REVENUE, COUNTY OF SAN DIEGO K-12 COMMUNITY GRANT PROGRAM FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$250,000.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Revenue: County of San Diego K-12 Community Grant Program Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with the County of San Diego to Accept K-12 Community Grant Program Funds for Hamilton Elementary School.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Receive $250,000.00 in grant funds. Revenue Budget String: 0135-90221-00-8699-0000-0000-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Hamilton Elementary School applied for and was awarded a grant from the County of San Diego for the K-12 Community Grant Program. Grant funds will be used to for:

 

  • Hamilton’s It takes a village I.T.A.V (I.V.A.T.) Program that aims to decrease chronic absenteeism rate, literacy gap and feelings of disconnectedness by increasing family involvement, knowledge and support.
  • Support the Hamilton Community through providing a full time Counselor, Family and Community Liaison as well as a Family Center. The Counselor will provide group counseling for students, families and community members as part of their services. These groups may focus on communication, self-esteem, trauma support, healing, restoration and academic success. In addition to Counseling groups, the Counselor will provide proactive and reactive classroom lessons and family workshops. In partnership with the Family and Community Liaison, the Counselor will ensure that the school provides for the basic needs of families and community members through a clothes boutique, food pantry, partnerships with medical clinics.
  • The Family and Community Liaison to provide 1:1 counseling to families on how they can best support their students at school. They will hold attendance support meetings to ensure families have the support they need to attend school daily. The Liaison will also manage the on-campus Family Center where families can have access to the internet, computers, books, Appendix A-3 homework centers, laundry machines, food, hygiene products and more! The Liaison will plan after school and during the day events that engage the community.
  • Creation of a Family Center: Funds will be used to make a family center. The funds would go towards paint, three computers, books to read with their children, homework supplies and furniture. The Family Center will be a space where students and families can safely complete homework and work with guidance and assistance. Many of our families experience modern homelessness and do not have access to safe spaces and materials to support their students with learning and homework. The family center will also be connected to a food pantry, clothes boutique, laundry closet and hygiene center to meet the immediate needs of the community. The Family Center will be open by appointment during school hours for student safety but will have daily open hours where families can come and complete the 15-20 minutes of daily suggested reading homework in a happy safe space. The Family Center would also host the monthly Family Book Club Meetings, School Budget Meetings and planning committees. Currently family meetings and reading time is held on the floor which is not as conducive to joyful and productive reading time. It will be a safe and welcoming space on campus that belongs to families to send the message that they matter!

 

[Originator/Contact: Ron Rode, Director, Research and Evaluation, Integrated Technology Division, 619.725.7190, rrode@sandi.net] 

File Attachments
K12CGP-COSDGrantAgreement2022-HamiltonElementarySchool.pdf (1,656 KB)

Subject
79. Approval of Human Resource Services Division Recommendations for New and Revised Position Descriptions; BUDGETED: YES, VARIOUS FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$149,789.76
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Various Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Approve the Human Resource Services Division recommendations for new and revised position descriptions.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: $149,789.76

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None. 

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. The recommendations reflect either no salary change or are an adjustment based on the current salary/pay additives of the incumbents in the classification.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: A well-written position description gives the reader an understanding of the basic and essential functions as well as the requisite knowledge, skills, and abilities required to perform successfully in the position. By updating position descriptions, we are able to clearly define the roles and interactions, and enhance the efficiency of the organization.

As part of the district’s obligation to maintain the classification plan and in response to requests from the bargaining units, management team, and recommendations from the joint labor-management Reclassification Committee, the Human Resource Services Division regularly provides recommendations for new and revised position descriptions. When applicable, and unless otherwise noted, the bargaining process has been completed for each position description presented in this item.

 

[Originator/Contact: Acacia Thede, Chief Human Resources Officer, 619.725.8043, athede@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
80. Ratification of Agreement with Okapi Educational Publishing, Inc., to Provide the Planning, Implementation, and Training of the Literacy Acceleration Program for District Students; BUDGETED: YES, TITLE I AND ESSER III FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$1,451,170.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Title I and ESSER III Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with Okapi Educational Publishing, Inc., to provide the planning, implementation, and training of the Literacy Acceleration Program in support of district students on behalf of the Leadership and Learning Department (PS23-0264-25).  Authorize the execution of any documents necessary to effectuate this Agreement. The term of this Agreement is August 1, 2022 through July 31, 2023.   

 

FISCAL IMPACT: The total not-to-exceed amount: $1,451,170.00.  

 

Budget String: 5474-30100-00-4101-1000-1110-01000-0000 and 5474-32131-00-4101-1000-1110-01000-0000.

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: For the period of August 1, 2021 through June 30, 2022: $6,121,386.69.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None. 

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.


BACKGROUND: Okapi Educational Publishing, Inc., and the district will continue partnering in the planning, implementation, and training of its students to support the Literacy Acceleration Program and allow digital access to thousands of books and resources during the 2022-23 school year.

 

This service will focus on building the district’s staff capacity, knowledge, and skill sets to provide vital Universal English Language Arts (ELA) Instruction to students in grades UTK-2. Okapi will provide professional development with direct support focused on district teachers with monthly learning institutes, reading instruction resources, online materials, monthly parent meetings, and benchmark curricular alignments.  The focus schools will be provided with monthly lesson studies and collaboration sessions, demonstration lessons, and co-facilitation of professional learning communities.  Teacher support will be given to the students reading and learning.

 

All professional development includes a variety of formats, including in-person and virtual learning.  Allowable under Elementary and Secondary Emergency Relief (ESSER) through addressing learning loss among students through implementing evidence-based activities to meet the comprehensive needs of students.

 

The board approves the agreement for a term of one year.   

 

[Originator/Contact: Maria Montgomery, Instructional Support Officer, Leadership and Learning, 619.725.7242, mmontgomery@sandi.net]

I. Superintendent's Consent Agenda
Subject
81. Ratification of Agreement with Math Transformations to Provide Math Content and Professional Learning Workshops for Math Resource Teachers, Enhanced Math Elementary School (EMES) Teachers, and Principals in EMES Schools; BUDGETED: YES, EDUCATOR EFFECTIVENESS FUNDS
Meeting
Sep 13, 2022 - Regular Meeting, 5:00 p.m.
Type
Action (Consent)
Fiscal Impact
Yes
Dollar Amount
$370,500.00
Budgeted
Yes
Budget Source
Educator Effectiveness Funds

RECOMMENDATION: Ratify Agreement with Math Transformations to provide math content and professional learning workshops for math resource teachers, Enhanced Math Elementary School (EMES) teachers, and principals in EMES Schools (PS23-0444-18). The term of this Agreement is August 15, 2022 through June 30, 2023.

 

FISCAL IMPACT: Total not-to-exceed amount: $370,500.00. Budget String: 5593-62660-00-5100-1000-3800-01000-0000. 

 

PRIOR YEAR FISCAL IMPACT: None.

 

IMPACT TO DISTRICT STAFFING: None.

 

CONSULTATION WITH BOARD ADVISORY COMMITTEE: Not applicable.

 

BACKGROUND: Math Transformations is guiding the intentional restructuring and networking of the Enhanced Math Elementary Schools (EMES) and providing professional learning that builds math leadership and instructional expertise across the Universal Transitional Kindergarten (UTK)-12th grade system (UTK refers to the district grade-level prior to kindergarten).

 

Math Transformations consultants will provide math professional learning for all district math resource teachers, Enhanced Math Elementary School teachers (via mentoring math resource teachers), and principals in the 21 EMES schools.  The professional learning focuses on growing the quality of math coaching, teaching, and learning across the system in alignment with the San Diego Enhanced Math (SDEM) Initiative.  It deepens students’ mathematical learning by developing teachers’ math content and pedagogical skills, strengthening teachers’ skills in using Enhanced Math’s guaranteed and viable curriculum, supporting coaches in working productively with principals and teachers, and building systemwide capacity for math teaching, learning, and collaboration. Math Transformations consultants provide professional learning through workshops, demonstrations, mentoring, and classroom coaching.  Professional learning is provided at multiple sites across the San Diego Enhanced Math Network.

 

[Original/Contact: Wendy Ranck-Buhr, Instructional Support Officer, Leadership and Learning, 619.725.7076, wranck-buhr@sandi.net]

Information

  • limit their remarks to not more than 3 minutes;
  • appoint a spokesperson if the concern is a group concern; and,
  • supplement verbal presentation with written reports, if necessary or desired.
